content:
Posted: April 21, 2015
												At first glance, I Am Alive showed a lot of promise. The post apocalyptic atmosphere is believable. The story feels genuine. But ultimately playing it felt more like a chore than entertainment. The game concepts sound great on paper, but fall short on execution. It tries to pretend it's open world, yet is completely linear. I tried to play as a passive person, purposely trying to save lives and ammo, but nothing I did or didn't do mattered. Just about everyone I encountered had to die because they were the aggressor and wouldn't step down. There was no way to talk my way out of any situation. And if I pointed my gun at someone without the intention of using it, they always attacked as soon as I lowered my weapon or tried to walk away. Killing people became routine and expected so eventually I just started shooting first.Then there's the stamina aspect which works well most of the time, until you unwittingly find yourself lost with no stamina to get back to safety, being forced to restart a level. And finally there's that genuine story which turns out to be nothing more than a dead end serving no purpose other than to keep the game moving forward. There is no closure here.Attaching the Ubisoft name to this title feels very similar to attaching the Gearbox name to Aliens: Colonial Marines--setting up high expectations, only to be disappointed.

content:
Posted: August 3, 2015
												Mixed reviews for this game confuse me, it deserves better. Don't get me wrong though, many things people complain about are true and the game really is relatively short (around 4 to 5 hours of gameplay) and abrupt, however it offers a very unique combat system and the overall atmosphere is pretty good. Playing on hard difficulty you will be forced into roungh resource managment (mainly ammo management, also water and other stuff), therefore you can't just wander anywhere you want neither can you shoot everything that moves, you have to force your enemies to surrender by threatening them with your (often times not even loaded) gun. I loved the concept and look forward to other games implementing it. The second most important aspect of the game is post-apocalyptic atmosphere, as mentioned above it is executed fairly well and the game feels somewhat unusual and therefore interesting.Surely, the game has it's flaws, they are mentioned in other reviews, However, I feel like most of them were brought up by people over-hyped by the game and therefore expecting it to be more than it actually can be. Some cons of the game I can think of is it's repetetiveness. Combat got somewhat repetetive but I am fine with that, what really annoyed me is climbing buildings over and over again (which was fun at first... but you can only climb so much without getting sick of it). And that's basically it, nothing else really stroke me during my first playthrough. To sum up, I can recommend this game. Get it if it's on sale and you are looking for something post-apocalyptic with survival aspects and unusual combat system. Just don't put your expectations for it too high and you will enjoy it as long as you keep all those bad reviews off your mind while playing.

content:
Posted: October 26, 2014
												You know what? Its really rather good. Its a good 12 hours worth of bleak post apocalyptic survival so provided you don't mind the complete lack of comedic relief then all good. In all seriousness, its a very playable game with some very clever elements. Holding a gun with only one bullet (or empty in some cases) and facing off against 3 enemy makes for some very quick strategic thinking of who to take down first, and who you can bluff into surrendering. The world setting is fantastic and a very believable vision of downtown US after the apocalyptic "Event". It really does feel that genuine. The plot is good enough, though relatively straightforward and although a little clunky at times, the control are sufficient. Had a couple of graphic glitches, and one dead end point where an enemy didn't spawn so I couldn't make the next objective. Also find that getting the enemies into that precise point to make a "strike" was tricky and it would often revert to the "struggle kill" with no warning. There's a good mix of the puzzle and platformer elements in the climbing sections and its challenging enough, even on the regular level setting.  Whilst the game is quite "samey" in that involves exploring climbing and a bit of combat, its fulfilling eoughIts not a cheery game by any standards (its on a par with say, Dead Space in terms of optimism) but its one that made me pretty happy. Overall score is a very comfortable 8 out of 10

content:
Posted: December 22, 2014
												I'm a sucker for the post-apocalypse genre - the grittier, the better - and thus this game looked really promising. Unfortunately, I ended up being severely disappointed.At first, the setting and mood was excellent, kinda like The Road (although thankfully not THAT harsh). I actually liked the stamina mechanism, too. In most games, your character is apparently a machine who can run/climb/fight/whine for hours without breaking a sweat, so such a nod to realism also got things started on the right foot. Graphics I didn't have much problem with, either. Hell, I grew up in the NES era, so I can forgive a lot on that score.Unfortunately, I Am Alive went downhill pretty quickly from there. It's funny that I mentioned the NES, because this game actually reminded me of the old NES games... in all the worst ways. It LOOKS like a GTA/Fallout-style open world at first, but looks are deceiving. I Am Alive is actually a linear game with constant barriers to keep you moving more or less along the one path. It's bitter that such an open-looking 3D world would offer so little room for exploration or experimentation.Looking at the map for the first time (before I became aware of this game's true nature), I actually wondered which streets I should take to the apartment. I thought "Okay, let's try those back streets, maybe less chance of being spotted by hostiles..." I soon learned that this game isn't big on exploration (or choices). That linear nature extended to the encounters, too. All too often, it felt like there was only one method or sequence to resolve things, with any other approach being punished brutally.That latter issue is made exponentially worse by the SAVE POINT SYSTEM. Even better, with limited retries! This is what nailed this game's coffin shut for me, the realization that this game came out in 2012 and oh wow, game designers STILL hadn't learned better than this idiocy.NO. This is no longer 1984 where you have to fit your entire game in 4 megabytes and I'm still a kid with enough free time to waste hours replaying the same fricking map over and over. If you want to encourage players to get through the game in less than X lives in one sitting, then hey, great. Make an achievement or a score bonus or a "hardcore mode" or whatever for it. But don't punish those of us who aren't masochists with nothing more interesting to do.You might think I'm a little hypocritical here, because I love roguelikes, which usually have permadeath and make you start over with a new character if you die. But the better ones (DCSS, DoomRL, ADOM, Sword of the Stars: The Pit) have random dungeons and classes that are very different from each other, so at least you can try something new if you die, with tons of room for exploration or just going some other way. I Am Alive should have borrowed more from that playbook if it wanted to be so harsh.TL;DR: This game is frustrating, stupidly linear, and has save points. Avoid.

content:
Posted: September 25, 2016
												I bought this game in sale for a low-price about 3 years ago but only played it a couple of months ago and was not disappointed; a good discovery i must say, for my part."I Am Alive" is a story-driven Third-Person (Shooter) game which takes place in a post-cataclysmic era, in a dark and dusty world, with a mostly black & white atmosphere. A lone survivor wants to retrieve his lost wife and daughter when the Event occured, one year ago.The player must collect resources to restore their Health and Stamina, but also to help other survivors who will give informations about the Event and your researched people. This is a choice, among others. Some survivors are hostile and quick decisions must be taken to stay alive... or not; intimidate and/or kill are sometimes the only way, but choose your priority target(s) precautionously, considering, furthermore, the rarity of ammo.The player has also to climb walls and edges, and there again good decisions are important concerning the way to take. You can find rare and precious pitons scattered in maps to be used wisely when out of Stamina while climbing.A thing i liked is the "Lives" (called "Retries" in the game) concept that was the core of ancient era games. Helping gentle/friendly survivors will reward the player with a "Retry".Some are scattered in the maps like those precious 1-Up we were happy to find in the games previous generation."I Am Alive" has pleasant graphics and gameplay mechanics.A con of this game is a  frequent "freeze & jerk" cam little bug that never lasts more than a couple of seconds. No big deal here, even if a bit annoying.The key mapping is also particular considering that you shoot, interact and run with the same button : Left Mouse. Not really intuitive when familiar with L-Shift key to run and usual E/F (and sometimes Space) keys to interact.To conclude, this short but (in my opinion) good game has a realistic aspect that makes it interesting. There are challenges to take. However i would recommend to buy it in sale regarding the cons above and its short duration.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												A rough hidden gem.(I beat this game originally on the PS3)Okay so it took Ubisoft: Shanghai 6 years to make the damn game and the age of it is immediately apparent.When I first laid my eyes on the game I could not believe the sight - the graphics were so horrendous that I died a little inside. I went on to adjust brightness and contrast to no avail; I could barely see any difference or improvement. The anti-aliasing in this game is about -2x or -4x, that's right MINUS. The jaggies are all over the place. The water is a mess. The textures are also extremely dated. I can't take screenshots on my PS3 (I could if the game was on Steam thank you very much) so I started taking photos with my phone and sharing it with my friend. He could not believe it either. Call me a spoiled PC gamer but the graphics really killed off a portion of immersion for me right off the bat. The graphics are below average, I am sure most console gamers will agree with me.However, one hour into the game and I was hooked. The civilization lays in ruins following a series of cataclysmic earthquakes and tsunamis; it's probably a pole shift. You arrive at the city in the search for your family with nothing but your back, some supplies, a flashlight and a camcorder (which is used for the cut scenes). Eventually get a machete, a gun, a shotgun and a bow. The game itself plays like a good survival movie. I've personally missed that genre for quite some time.If you venture too far out into the dust-filled streets your stamina and health will slowly drain so you always have to make sure that you have enough supplies to replenish your stamina and health lest you suffocate and die. About that dust...It's been a year since the event and the dust still hasn't settled. So on one hand it's intriguing to not be able to see further than 6 feet away and struggle to get your bearings but on the other hand this trick can be viewed as a cop out on the part of the developers since they obviously haven't put much effort into graphics. The sound is good though. I played without the music. I liked the dead silence of the dead city.You get to meet a total of 20 survivors in the game and help them out with supplies and other miscellaneous items so I advise you to save your supplies till the last and not use them until you meet someone who needs them. Helping every survivor will grant you an additional retry. This feature is helpful if you are playing on the survival mode which I heavily recommend for maximum immersion. Basically if you play on survival then you will be extremely cautions. And that's one of the biggest things that glued me to the game. It's that there is no trial and error here, you really have to think your moves ahead. I once got stranded on the other side of the mall and it took me my last two retries, most of my supplies and two pitons (used to rest while climbing) to find my way out. All in all, I spent about 30 minutes trying to find my way back in order to avoid starting the episode all over again.I am actually surprised that the devs managed to make climbing interesting. Uncharted was probably the first game to do so but this game implements much more realism and puzzle solving when it comes to that. You can play as Nathan Drake, hang on the ledge and then go make yourself a veggie sandwich. By the time you come back Drake will still be here, hanging on a cliff above the abyss. That won't happen in this game. There is a small cliffhanger almost every time you climb somewhere. You have to make out the path in your head and figure out if you'll have enough stamina to climb to your destination. Your stamina will start draining, the ominous music will set it and your palms might start getting sweaty in real life.As for the gameplay itself, well it delivers. When you aim you get the biggest, most ablest auto-aim I have ever seen in a video game. When you face the enemies you either have the choice of running, facing them head on, fooling them by attempting to do a surprise kill or subduing them by killing the leader of the gang. It's kind of like a checkers game. If you kill that one, then the two will rush you, if you kill that one then maybe you'll survive. If you try to rush the guy who has a gun with your machete then you will die. There are also a couple of stealth kills in the game. I have also exploited this trick to have the enemy AI shoot one of their own accidentally if you align yourself correctly. It worked every time and I saved myself health and ammo. About that ammo, yeah, the most bullets I was able to muster at one time in the game was 7 bullets.A few more things that hampered the immersion for me. You don't talk back to the survivors, ever, you just stand there and listen. The bodies of the slain enemies disappear unfortunately. Some food items mysteriously reappear in some locations. Many AI (a guy with harry potter glasses) reappear in the game. For a total of 50 something enemies they could easily made more AI models. You can also kill some peaceful civilians without any repercussions. Upon their imminent death they will likely curse you for taking their life when they meant you no harm. At one point in the game you may actually kill a kid's parents by mistake. The story was okay and I liked the bleak melancholic ending.All in all in took me 8 hours to beat the game.  The whole game takes place around only 4-6 square city blocks. The game also only occupies 2GB of hard drive space. Ubisoft could have really turned this into a franchise. They could easily make a sequel or a prequel but I guess it's not on their priority list.

content:
Posted: March 20, 2014
												I Am Alive was the very reason I started using the screenshot taking feature Steam offers. Probably most of the pictures I took were uploaded for this game only. I am still perplexed why people call this game ugly. It's environment is simply gorgeous. I look at the big picture here not tiny details such as not near perfect antialiasing or the highest HD textures available in current generation video games. Simply the city our protagonist arrives to looks stunning and depressing and superb. This desolate city is characterised by grey and white colours due to the fog, dust and toxic waste present and the beams of the sun shining through the sky are the most beautiful I have ever seen in a video game. Those being more expert in this area will probably challenge me - I have found this game visually stunning, regardless. I took numerous pictures especially when you climb the skyscrapers - those sequences are outstanding.Gameplay-wise I Am Alive is a rather difficult TPS game. Even a single enemy can easily kill you. You have melee weapons at your disposal and any firearms you have provide you only with limited ammo. You need to plan every single encounter very carefully. The only letdown when it comes to this game its shortness. It can be completed in 5 or 6 hours with all side missions completed and collectibles obtained. Still, it is forgivable considering the budget was rather low for this one and also it's easy to catch this gem at a discounted price.

content:
Posted: October 21, 2016
												I have so much I want to write about this game. I'll start with 'I love it', anyway, let's get that out of the way first.I am Alive had a long and problematic development cycle. At one stage, Ubisoft had intended to start a franchise with this game. I can see how it could have been as successful as Assassin's Creed or Far Cry. There are similarities to The Last of Us which of course became a huge success for, developer, Naughty Dog.The reality though, is that in the end the game was released, in a stripped down and relatively short state. It can be completed in around five hours but it does have a lot of replay value. There are achievements, which for some reason are not registered on Steam but can be found on the game's Main Menu screen.This game is a lot of fun, the combat sytem is unique, the climbing sequences are amazing and the game world is genuinely interesting. While I am playing, I can really see the potential I am Alive had to be just as successful as any other Ubisoft game. There are gameplay elements that were innovative at the time of it's release. I'd bet money that some major game developers have been influenced by this game. I think the combat system, though, is unique even to this day and it's really cool.However, I am Alive's tone is maybe a bit too miserable for most people, including myself. So what I did was, I turned off the depressing in game music and added a SweetFX profile for more colour. Technically, the game ran great for me on a GTX 980, running Windows 10, at a solid 60FPS. There are some low resolution textures and some dodgey lighting affects but the game looks great for the most part. The game world is dynamic and believable from the top of ruined sky scrapers, to down on the streets, below the killer dust.I am Alive is now one of my favourite games and in a way I'm glad the game ended up as it is, It's a hidden little gem, that most people over look, which just makes me love it even more.  I highly recommend that you give it a try!!

content:
Posted: September 9, 2015
												I had really high hopes for this game. Before it came out, I remember seeing all kinds of press for it, screenshots of vast urban decay, hints of in-depth exploration, all the features that make a post-apocalypse fan salivate. Yet the hype for it died completely off after release, and I actually completely forgot it existed until I saw it on a Steam sale. I finally decided to pick it up and play it. Right from the start there were multiple things that bothered me. The game doesn't seem to want to go too far in any direction no matter what the choice is, and that makes it overall very bland right from the get-go. The game is incredibly linear, guiding you in a single direction and not letting you veer off the course, yet they have tiny outlets from your linear path where you can find consumable items and whatnot. It's not rewarding to get these though. There was virtually no effort put into finding it aside from ♥♥♥♥ing off somewhere that wasn't the objective and after a short 5 second walk it's sitting on the ground for you. Why didn't they have the ability to search for supplies? checking dumpsters, containers, or piles of debris would have added so much more to this than simply walking slightly left of where you were originally going to go. The interactions with the AI are just as linear as the exploration. There are two types of people in the game, the "I'm just trying to survive, morally you shouldn't shoot me" people and the "I'm clearly up to no good, you shouldn't feel bad shooting me" people. It makes it very cut and dry to be able to decide who to kill and who not to, and don't worry, if the game decides you shouldn't kill someone it does its best to prevent that. One of the first NPCs you meet in the game is a woman protecting her storefront/residence with a gun. If you walk in front of her, she'll point the gun at you and warn you to stay back. The game clearly wants you to just leave her alone and keep walking, but the game hints from the tutorial that you should have to make the choice yourself as to what you do in that situation. Yet in this situation, you have at most 1 round for your handgun, clearly dissuading you from shooting her. You have a machete, but due to her placement you can't sneak up to her for a stealth kill like you have just been taught how to do, and if you walk at her and try to kill her with it she immediately plugs you in the head and kills you. You're supposed to think "Well duh, that's how it would be in real life" but it is disappointing that they force that kind of situation on you with the facade of choice and moral decisions being involved when in actuality the game has forced your moral compass to point to "Good". This is just one of my many complaints about the game. The camera is horrible, switching between a free camera and being locked in certain angles that gets incredibly jarring. The combat is incredibly simple and redundant, as is the urban exploration with things like traversing obstacles, climbing ledges, hanging from pipes, etc.. The stamina meter built into the climbing is nothing more than, to use a cliche term, artificial difficulty. It's meant to add a sense of urgency, stress, or fear in the game, but yet they give you the simplest exploring mechanics of all time. All of it is incredibly safe. If you mess up an input, it's not like you fall to your death, you just sit there doing nothing. You can't fall off a ledge, there is no balancing on the beams as you cross them. It's meant to give you the feeling that it's dangerous, without actually giving the player any reason to be scared. All in all, the game is a major disappointment, and I can't say I would recommend it to anyone expecting an immersive or exciting game.

												Biggest let down of a story/atmosphere driven game i've ever played.  It's fun-ish, pretty interesting and definitially different than the usual games out there, but their story writer needs to be shot.  Honestly and without hyperbole, this is a great story made terrible by (most likely) budget and time constraints.  More specificially, they just droped act 2 & 3 in favor of "ps. hero did stuff and... CREDITS!" Summary:-- the story sucks... really badly. leaving a negative after taste (probably why all the bad reviews)- dont believe the marketing, its not ground breaking at all- can be rather clunkyBUT++ level design is really good!++ atmosphere+ combat is snazzy and differentRecommendation? While i cant say you SHOULD get the game, consider the following:While the value of the work put into the game is likely worth the list price ($15), the game net experience is worth around $9 - Use that advice however you wish.

I Am Alive gives players a pure survival experience at a low price. It is a short game, easily completed in 6 hours or so if you run through it.The reason Im at 9 hours is simply because I wanted to explore more of the world and do some little side quests that there is very little reward for.However, dont be fooled, this is a beautiful gameI Am Alive thrusts you into the role of a lone survivor in a believable, dark and insecure post-apocalyptic world. One year after the Event, a worldwide cataclysmic event that wiped most of the human race, a man struggles for survival in a desolate city as he tries to reunite with his long lost wife and daughter.Pros+ I Am Alive is brutal; gripping; captivating; depressing; miserable; and almost always utterly brilliant.+ Storytale & development of both character and storyline is amazing+ Emotional rollercoasterCons- Linear game- Short - A game without a concluded ending

Posted: June 22, 2016
I Am AliveIt's a tough call but ultimately, I just can't recommend this game. If you push through the first couple of hours like I did, you may find something worth actually seeing the game through to the end. But I'd argue that that would be working too hard for something that's supposed to be fun and enjoyable from the get-go.Pros:Tends to get slightly better as you progress;Interesting resource-based strategic combat system;Scarce resources do add a sense of pressure to decision making in Survivor mode;Stamina brings a bit of welcome tension to free climbing;Good voice acting for the most part;Decent soundtrack;Cons:A lot of original ideas that were poorly executed;Overly linear progression focused on climbing;The Fog adds to the mood but hampers the will to explore;Helping people ends up feeling like a chore;Dated graphics and animations, coupled with frame rate issues;Frustrating controls and immersion-breaking game prompts;Constant tension-building music indicator when using stamina gets old really fast.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2016
Teal DeerDevelopers: Ubisoft ShanghaiPublishers: Ubisoft Initial release: Sept 2012Genre: Action, Lite Survival, Adventure#Worth/NotWorth: #WaitForSaleBSERC - (Borderline Sardonic and Extremely Reductive Comparison): “Not” Nathan Drake in off brand Fallout/generic post apocalypse, Consistent in having a dearth of color saturation and an unruly grip meter. Think Shadow of the Colossus except it gets worse instead of better as Solid Snake and/or Raiden would attest to.Exposition, Concurrence and SummationI am Alive is.. well it's not great. But it isn't the worst way to spend your time either. You play as Carlo Mestroni attempting to find his family after [the event]. It is never made entirely clear what, how, why, or indeed even when the world has become this way. It just is, so deal with it. Early on, Carlo finds some purpose in aiding a child he mistakes as his daughter. Without going too far down the story path; She is very important to the goings on and the objectives that will befall you. I mention this only to inform that she is not a hindrance as in there is no “true” escort mission. This isn't Resident Evil 4. She is attached to you for most intents and purposes and cannot die unless you do. The survival aspect of the game comes from needing to manage your grip meter and health. If you stay on ledges too long or over exert yourself you'll find that your overall ability to stay on non flat surfaces decreased. Throughout the environment you'll find some items that can restore your health, energy as well as replenish your overall capacity for overexertion. There is also the dust mechanic. Wherein being too low in elevation where the dust has still not settled it is impossible to recover any energy and you must get to higher ground to do so; This can lead to some tense if not annoying sequences of trying to figure out where to go whilst trying not to use all your gear and resources.  The main loop and danger of the game comes from traversal. Very tense music plays when low on energy and it can be quite nerve racking. The other side of the game is dealing with other survivors. Some hostile immediately, others just scared. The combat is not especially great. It is indeed quite functional however stilted though it may be. It consists of holding a pistol up to threaten would be assailants. And then kick them off of edges or into fires and so forth. You must keep you gun trained on all the enemies lest they take advantage of your indecision. Perhaps they may even suggest you've not got the gall. If you relax, you can trick the enemies into coming closer and surprise kill them. This is one aspect that feels great. As during their approach you must quickly ascertain which if any other members of the group have a firearm. And take them out as soon as possible after your surprise kill. It can feel very tactical and systematic especially when ammo is scarce.  The game relies on retries or continues if you will. And you can earn more through helping or aiding the non enemy combatants you'll run into. The main city you'll revisit throughout the campaign so you'll get slightly accustomed to it as well as come back for people you were not able to aid before. As you may expect you eventually earn things that make traversing the dust less annoying. As well as other things that make running out of energy less of an issue. But they are near the end of the game and you don't really get to use them much. The game is about five-ish hours in total. THE GISTThe game draws a lot of small features from numerous sources and puts it into a relatively poorly executed package. However, for the right sale price I think those ideas are worth checking out.Follow my curation for more

content:
Posted: October 9, 2014
												Although there are some flaws, the game is extremelly enjoyable, and as its price is very low now, it is a good catch.Pros: The designers created a truly horrific atmosphere: the game has scenes of sexual abuse, cannibalism and bleak morality, alhtough none of them are gratuitousGood design: the game uses brutality to inform its simple mechanics. You have to scale buildings, using windowsills and drainpipes for handholds, to achieve your objectives, and all those actions are tense because of your limited stamina - if your stamina reaches zero, you will fall to your death. So, the game forces you to use your resources at the right time or you will fail.The game's setting – an American city, with all its skyscrapers cracked and its streets empty save for abandoned, rusting roadblocks.Combat is tense too. Your char will always be short of ammunition, but will be facing large groups of enemies. Because of this setup, you will be forced to use surprise and your environment to survive. (as an example, in one of the encounter one of the best solutions is to slice the throat of the first person to get too close, then pull a gun on the remaining bandits and force them to back up against a ledge before kicking them to their deaths).The bow and its two arrows (believe me, this one deserves the praise - you will be using it a lot)Cons:Because you face so many enemies from middle to the end of the game, you will end up repeating the same encounter many times, always following the same routine: surprise kill, shoot, ledge kick, etc.The climbing, while tense, can become a grind, specially in the beginning of the game.The ending: it seems the game was finished midway of its story. So, the main reason of the character going all the hardships will not be answered.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												Terribly disappointing. Really, really disappointing.There are some games that, when I see them, I get hooked and tend to ignore most bad reviews. Sometimes, that is a wise choice, as I have found MANY games that I've loved that had terrible reviews all around. But other times, that is a terrible move, as the reviews are true.In this case, the bad reviews are true. I am Alive is, well, terrible.I was hooked since the first trailer ever released, and I never played it until now. Now, I wish I hadn't. I didn't want to just drop the game, as I hate doing that, so I just tried to play through as quickly as possible, ignoring the in-game achievements. Thankfully there are no Steam achievements, as I would hate to see the partial completion in that.Anyway, to the point: Don't buy this game. The controls are horrible. Getting a controller helps, but it's still wonky. The combat is no good. You can sneak attack someone, which is cool at first, but it wears off. Besides that, you can shoot people but ammo is TERRIBLY scarce. I understand that this game is survivalist, but your guy has been out there forever, and he begins the game with like a water bottle and that's it.The only other way to fight is with your knife. If the combat was more action-oriented, then it would have been better. Instead, you're usually screwed when fighting gangs. Your only knife attack (besides the sneaking one to get the first edge-up) is to run up to someone's face and proceed into a button-mashing event while you're left open to all other baddies. Your guy can't just stab and slash in an active manner. Instead, he can only lock his knife with the other guy and sit there while being shot. And each time he's shot, the event has to be restarted.Therefore, combat is terrible. It should have been more fluid and action-oriented.And as for the climbing... God, such a pain. I liked what they were trying to do at first, but then got over it quickly. Again, it's a survivalist game, but it is just too much. You have a fatigue meter which, when you lose enough fatigue, also will lose its capacity. If you don't have items to restore capacity, you're screwed and usually find yourself in a vicious circle of needing to find items which require either (a) ammo to shoot a lock or (b) you to climb somewhere. But chances are you're looking for ammo already, or you're looking for an item to help you climb. So often you're forced to restart places or re-attempt entire sections.And the graphics--they look like someone digitalized sawdust and filtered it through the imagery. The game can still look ugly and apocalyptic without looking... THAT kind of ugly.There's more issues, as I found many glitches along the way, the story was lackluster, and on and on and on.Overall, I was terribly disappointed. Do not play this game.

number of helpful: 28 of 41 people (68%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 2, 2015
												I Am Alive is actually a very refreshing and entertaining game. - Through the dusty city in fictional city Haverton in America, there was a backstory known as 'The Event', that apparently was a bunch of earthquakes, though the backstory of post-apocalyptic essentially is present. The story is a series of events that occur in Haverton, which I must admit use a variety of buildings and adventures in order to fulfill the objectives, refreshing. The overall story is powerful through emotionally engaging with characters, for example, Mei and her mother. The story does tend to rush at the end as that could have been spaced out, though I will admit the ending is very strong and I was completely shocked by the ending. Oh, its a cliffhanger too.- The graphics are beautiful in the game. For a 2012 game, they are at a high standard for that point in time. Speaking of Ubisoft, in 2012 they had a high standard of graphics in each game they released, which was their year in relation to graphics. The atmosphere and environment and the day/night dynamic is excellent graphically, though there could be some more day/night variations.- The gameplay is solid. I do like the motions of the character and how he engages with the environment, which I felt was again for a lack of better word, refreshing, though different to other post-apocalyptic games. These same motions however, could be expanded a lot more. For example, if your character is on the ground, your stamina will deplete due to heavy dust that will affect it and eventually your health. The character walks basically like he is having a stroll as if there was minimal dust. To combat this, more diversity in actually producing motions when in the heavy dust could add a further dynamic to the gameplay. Stamina added a new dynamic to the game, which I appreciated. I liked the fact that this element suggested planning more so you as a player wouldn't deplete your stamina as fast as if you just went out there, so it was nice. I did love the element of preserving your bullets, as they could come in at handy times. There are a limited number of bullets in the game, and you do need them, though thats why planning is essential.Regarding crooks and other gang members, I loved that element in the game, though it did get repeatitive as it was too basic. So everytime you walked up to a crook, you would have to kill him essentially, no reasoning, nothing, just plain old re-shooting the guy, whilst good, repeatitive. The camera control is an absolute pain. For example, whilst on a cliff and you look at the scenery and attempt to plan what portions of the building you have to climb, the camera will literally screw you up by making you deplete stamina because the camera was not facing the direction your player was moving at. - There were bugs regarding graphics and gameplay that could have been ironed out, and balancing regarding camera control would have been appreciated. It didn't overly affect the game, but it was noticeable. Not as bad as some games I'll mention. Here are my pros/cons based off this review...Pros:- Strong story and backstory.- Beautiful graphics.- Day/Night dynamic, Atmosphere, and Environment are very good.- Solid gameplay.- Lovely balance overall.Cons:- Rushed ending to story.- Day/Night could have been used more to enhance particular missions, apparently according to the main character near the end, the entire sequence of events happened in a day...- Vague, but gameplay could be expanded upon.- Bugs.Overall, I Am Alive is a good game. It has its positives and negatives, however it has a very good foundation to build upon. The gameplay was solid, though it was basic for this genre and could have been more diverse to enhance the game. The story was strong, and the graphics were great. I do recommend this game at $17.99, however it is you, the readers, choice because I played this game on easy mode (there are 3 or 4 levels of difficulty) and it took me 8 hours to complete the game. So expect at least 10+ hours if you do the side-quests as well, as in help the surviviors. I did this partially (7/20). Score: 7.5/10EDIT: I forgot to mention, dialogue is excellent in the game. Every set of people, be it main characters or thugs had dispirate dialogue, enhancing the game. I loved that aspect. Since I forgot to mention that, I'll bump my score from 7.25-7.5/10.EDIT 2: This game lets you run your mind run wild on what happened to Haverton, what happened at the ending. It leaves a lot of aspects open for interpretation which works for this game. I forgot to mention, this game sometimes can feel like a chore to play, but personally that is what happened to me when I raged that I kept dying in the dust :p----Thanks for reading my review! If you like my reviews and care to read more, feel free to join Antwog's Analysis (Reviews). http://steamcommunity.com/groups/AntwogReviewsIf you have questions comment below or post in Antwog's Analysis (Reviews) general discussion page. If you liked it, give it a rating.

												The game was good for its time. It came out on March 7, 2012. The Last of Us came out on June 14, 2013. Some people say this game is a wannabe of The Last of Us, but I do not see how that is possible. The storylines and gameplay are different from one another. What I like the best about the game was that you had to think about how you were going to take down your enemies with limited supplies. I did not like seeing the stamina gauge at the top of the screen during every second of gameplay. I would have liked it to show only when in use. I played this game on Windows 8 with no problems. I wish there was sequal to this game with updated game play. Achievments/trophies  are not supported by Steam, but there is a trophy system in the game itself. The Playstation 3 version does support trophies.

number of helpful: 31 of 47 people (66%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 3, 2016
												In my opinion, this game missed out on so much. You're brought into a world/environment that could be rife with background and stories but somehow they manage to leave you (or me, at least) feeling both wanting to know more about it and also not caring about what is told about what happened. A lot fo the comments about whatever took place feel like a passing explanation - as if no thought has been put into it and just trying to brush it off.The main character's story/search feels COMPLETELY dismissed for 95% of the game. I can understand being a character that wants to help people but when it comes to the point of getting home and not finding what you wanted, right there it seems to be thrown onto the backburner. The character says now and then "Oh I'm here doing this" - NO YOU'RE NOT! You get thrown on everyone else's errands. When it does loop back to the point he is going to continue onto his search, I found I just couldn't care less anymore.When it comes to the controls, they just seem...off. I kept finding myself climbing down onto ledges without meaning to, not being able to jump down or climb up when I NEEDED to - leading to me dying. Or aiming at an enemy and suddenly it aims at the one without the gun, or on one occassion I found I died because while trying to aim at a particular enemy the auto-aim just kept looping through the FOUR that were closing in on me. And it's so very repetitive! There's so much climbing that it just ends up with no tension as your stamina decreases because you've seen/heard it a million times, and it just feels like a chore. I thought things would get more interesting when they brought in the rope-swing but found it only gets used a couple of times, and then it's so stiff and lifeless that it just sucks you out of the game further.I've actually recorded this as a series on my YT channel and the honest reason I continued it until the end was how ridiculous it was trying to do anything. Parts were rage-inducing, but mostly it was laughable at how stupid it all seemed. I'm glad I played through it just so I know how rubbish I found it, but I would recommend others to just go onto YouTube and watch it. Or if you are going to buy it, make sure it's on one hell of a sale.

												I know there are a lot of critics raving about how much they hate this game, but I'm just gonna come out and say it: I love it. Even though the graphics aren't perfect, and the colour scheme is mildly bland, I love the gritty, dark and dusty feel to the game. The story line is bittersweet and I really liked the AI, because although some of the lines were cheap, the split second decision to draw/not draw your weapon, point an empty gun at someone (bullets are hard to come by) was somehow... pretty lifelike. I especially enjoyed the obstacle courses, with the added adrenaline of knowing that you only have a certain amount of stamina to perform tasks. I would definitely say, get it while it's on special... but do yourself a favour and get it :) you might just end up enjoying it too!

content:
Posted: August 28, 2014
												First off despite its flaws I think I Am Alive is a pretty epic post apocalyptic survival experience unlike anything I've ever played before. For a budget game it has mostly exceeded my expectations by managing to perfectly encapsulate the scarcity of resources and that dusty, ruble-y ruined post apocalyptic world setting. Though my favorite aspect of the game would have to be the mind games you're forced to play with your enemies. Imagine having to shoot the biggest guy in the group with your bow in hopes of getting the smaller ones to surrender, then whipping out your handgun with 0 ammo in order to intimidate the remaining foes just so you can retrieve your only arrow from the corpse to kill off some more scavengers with it. Secondly its a console port with a weird♥♥♥♥♥control scheme, sure you can rebind the keys but its still felt pretty weird, I think its best played with a controller although you'll most likely be fine with kb/m and Thirdly I did not experience any performance issues with it at all, it ran at a constant 60fps all the way through, the only problem is that its locked at 60 even with vsync off and editing the config file did not unlock the buttery smooth 144hz experience. noUplayFTW /10

number of helpful: 9 of 10 people (90%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 11, 2015
												I'm not really sure if I should recommend this game or not.To me, This game was incredible in design and mechanics. The trailer versus the end result did leave me wanting though, I expected a bit, no, alot more.This is an unfinished game to say the least, it won't take you more than a few hours to complete, and once you do, you don't feel like you did anything really, it's not an open world game, HAH! you wish.The only hint you get as to what happens when this is all done, is that your character is 85% dead, and 15% Missing in action.Not a good ending for an otherwise decent game. I just wish the game had an open world, and was a little more fleshed out, as well as having a dynamic day-and night cycle, but nope.It's been a few years since this game came out, so let my in-game time speak for itself, i completely finished this games storyline.... Three times. sooooo, 23 divided with 3? That makes a little more than 7 hours per playthrough.8 hours is the average minimum playsession For a person like me, take a guess how I felt after beating this game the same day I bought it. Not very pleased.Now then, as for mechanics? there's alot of nice aspects here, but also alot of pit-falls. You'd think your character could climb stuff, right? Nope, only when it's an obvious spot. If you can't obviously see the spot to climb, you can't climb it. And even then, it doesn't feel natural.E V E R Y T H I N G that happens in this game is scripted to happen, down to even the ''loot'' you can find, oh, and it doesn't appear to respawn either, if it does, i've been too quick doing the quests in this game, since there was literally nothing else to do.combat is a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ that's all I can say. I can't really remember it well, but I don't think your character can swing his weapon at all, if he can, it's so slow that any enemy can just interrupt you. And ammo is so scarce, that you'll want to save it till the last part.You are going to die ALOT int this game, and 75% of your deaths, are going to be cheap shots. with about half of those cheap shots being developer created pitfalls in the climbing areas in this game.So, what can I say? I don't recommend this game, had it been longer, maybe. If they had made this an open world game, and added sidequests? Definitely.But as it stands, I can't say yes to this game, not for this price, wait for it to go on sale. It's definitely something you'll want to try, but don't spend your hard earned cash expecting this to be a revelation of some sort. It's not.

number of helpful: 8 of 9 people (89%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 3, 2016
												I Am Alive kind of makes you feel like you're an urban post-apocalyptic Tomb Raider that can climb almost as well as Lara Croft, but you don't have the stamina or the tight buns to make climbing as enjoyable. In fact climbing can be be stressful because of the stamina mechanic, but it does provide a nice challenge in a game that is more survival oriented than a treasure hunting puzzle solving game. Everything except walking will drain your stamina - climbing, running, executing, walking through dust... Don't worry though, you recover stamina quickly, and if you find yourself in a scenario where you can't stop and rest, just keep drinking soda and you'll find all the energy you'll need to get through.The idea they used where you can have a stand-off by pointing a gun (even when it's empty) to make people keep their distance, or even make them surrender, is nice, but it almost always plays out so that they will call you chicken and attack you anyway, which is kind of frustrating given that bullets are hard to come by. Also, you'll take a little girl under your care so it's not just yourself you need to worry about, but apart from some story missions about getting her medicine, she doesn't really need anything to keep her alive. You don't have to feed her or give her water, the only problem is that you have to piggy back her around which means you can't run - but you can still jump and climb so whatever, it's better than having a hopeless NPC follow you around and messing up your mission.I wasn't terribly impressed by the graphics, and a lot of the time you're just in a grainy black and white dust storm which suits the story, but it's a bit overdone. It's still holding up fairly well for a game from 2012, but it's probably getting close to it's best before date.Works well with an Xbox 360 controller.7 out of 10. Would drink more soda in a dust storm.

number of helpful: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2013
												I Am Alive... or Am I Dead?Ok, game that was in development for a really long time. Heck it was announced at E3 2008 and the game had been shadowing the gaming industry for a long while; even having rumors of cancellation. Alas, it finally got out on consoles at first, then on PC in September 2012. So what is this game? You play as some dude, returning to Havington, a year later after some "EVENT" occured. No info about what the event is... So you head to that city to find your lost wife and daughter only to stumble upon an asian kid and her mother. Then you go around and try to keep them safe while fighting some other survivors that made gangs.PROS:-The setting is nice, dust everywhere so the cataclismic feel is there.-Ambiance, sounds, voice acting and even the graphics are decent.-Inventory management-Decent action and can threat enemies with empty gunCONS:-Poor checkpoint system-Poor "retry mode" system that if you die and out of "retries", you restart till last checkpoint.-Mouse look in this game is atrocious and even freeze often-Exploration is pointless as you need to go into toxic street levels that drains your stamina, only to find soda cans that replenish stamina.-Very linear.-Gangs only agressive vs you and not other gangs.-Crap ending.Worth buying?ONLY at discount! I Am Alive can provide you a good 5-7 hours of playtime... more if you seek to help every refugees.RATING: 5 / 10===SPOILER ALERT===The final cinematic of the game ends with a character crying. There is a good reason for that – I Am Alive is such a waste of a great concept.

content:
Posted: July 26, 2014
												I was really impressed by this game. It's immense atomsphere of post-apocalyptic city with no usual zombies aboard just made me forget about all the weak spots (and there are lots of them). Really deep immersion into the setting. You feel alone, scared and depressed all the time. As I already mentioned there are no zombies or aliens or any other fictional stuff. It is a sad grey quest through desolated concrete jungle filled with murderers, rapists and few normal people who are mostly busy with... well, dying. Some gameplay mechanics (such as stamina loss when climbing or suffocating on the bottom levels covered with dust) came out to be very good ideas for making the game closer to real life. Lack of supplies makes it more challenging - you won't be running around with pockets full of different types of ammo and various goods.However, if we speak about the tech part, I Am Alive is far from perfect. I would say that the graphics are very avearge for a product of 2012. It feels more like a game of 2008. The makers did pretty bad job for a product that has been in development for like 5 or 6 years. Sometimes it felt like the they didn't put much effort in this title (especially when everyone were waiting for The Last of Us which came out a year later).Anyway, I do recommend this game for anyone who likes post-apocalyptic settings. It has a unique atmosphere and is definitely worth trying.

number of helpful: 11 of 17 people (65%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 4, 2015
												First thing's first - don't let the mixed reviews scare you off.I guess detrimental to its success was the fact that this game came out way before the whole survival/resource-management shtick came into fashion.Despite what you may read, the game is pretty enjoyable. Granted, you shouldn't play the whole thing in one sitting. Also because it's fairly short. But considering it probably never was planned as one, nor was it given the budget to be a major release (and it shows), the end product turned out great imho.The atmosphere and graphics are decent, the gameplay too. Yes, the camera rotation and player movement tend to hickup every now and then, but not in a 'deal-breaker' way. Another thing I thoroughly enjoyed was that there wasn't 'one correct way' to get from A to B. Sure, when it came to getting from one quest location to another, the game is pretty linear, but at the locations themselves you can get into dead ends, so this will force the player to really think their actions through. Which is refreshing.It is also refreshing, because the game WILL punish you if you are careless. Or reckless.And it is very thorough in doing so.Forget saving at will. You get checkpoints. And you get limited retry tokens. Stamina depleting during climbing also makes you reconsider the routes you take.  None of that willy-nilly climbey monkey BS in Assassin's Creed. :PBullets? Limited. Arrows? Better strategize, because you need to draw it first and that gives your foes plenty of time to run up and butcher you.The only thing I didn't really like was the lack of closure in the storyline. I mean, not to divulge any spoilers, but it really leaves the player thinking like it ended too soon. Like there's a chunk of the story we didn't get to see/play/experience. And that is a pity. Yet Ubisoft has obviously it's priorities and funds elsewhere.Oh, and before I forget - best part? It DOESN'T use uplay.TL;DR - MEAN every bullet, LOOK before you climb, micromanage to survive. 7 decent hours of fun if you're into survival sims.

number of helpful: 13 of 21 people (62%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 28, 2014
												So, I'm gonna make this one short. I really enjoyed I AM ALIVE but once you look at the game on the paper it pretty much sucks.On the plus side we have:+Fun.+Good Story.+A decent morality system that I will talk about in a second.+The difficulty is nothing crazy but satisfying.+SOME good character dialog.On the other hand we have:-The awful Graphics.-The bad combat system.-The game took me around 5 hours to complete and I also did most of the side missions.-Minor bugs(nothing too bad)-That annoying dust filter in sequences where you are outside of the dust.The (kind of) morality system:Now there isn't much of a real morality system other than a few things like "don't steal", don't eat humans". Those things will give a small boost to your endscore. However I found myself thinking about my victims as you will often find yourself in a place where YOU raid a camp. The bad thing  about this that instead of actually putting some people that are innocent where you can kill them to make you think about who you shoot. I only killed 3 innocents while playing and every time there was a way around them, the game however does not give you the possibility to skip "bad" guys(yoiu CAN skip some but it is usually much harder). Then again you have the possibility to execute your enemies which will give you no bonus other than the feeling of justice/douchbaggery(maybe, that is).Final Verdict:I had a lot of fun with this game and it didn't frustrate me at all, the story is good but the price is a bit too high. I'd say buy it but maybe wait for a sale, unless you are a huge fan of post-apocalyptic games then grab a paysafe card and buy this little UBI pearl. ~AndGeo

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												I Am Alive might have been a great game but it manages to fall over itself in several critical categories. The first is atrociously awful combat, where you are saddled with an avatar who has only two combat moves and both are ridiculously hobbled. The first is shooting a gun, which is effective in dealing with enemies but ammunition is purposely in extremely short supply. The second is melee combat, but the only move you can make is to grapple with an enemy and jab a knife into their midsection, and that move can be interrupted by getting hit. Essentially this means you are helpless against groups, because you won't have enough ammunition to take down all the enemies and melee is impossible against more than one person. Of course, the game frequently throws you against groups. Toss in a hobbled save-game system (save-points, and only a handful of retries before you have to restart the entire level) and combat becomes a game-killer. The platforming, the other half of the game, is too cumbersome and limited to make exploration enjoyable, and the dreary, limited graphics mean you won't want to wander the world anyway. The game does open up some after a while, becoming far less linear than its first few levels make it appear, but there's really not that much to do in the world so there's no point. And just when you think you are starting to make progress, the game suddenly ends, with no resolution or even a climax. It's a disappointing game on so many levels.

content:
Posted: January 9
												This game is really good, one of a handful of games I've ever played that really surprised me. You can read more in-depth reviews by others, I'll just say that I Am Alive is not really like anything else you've ever played before.It has two gameplay elements that really got me hooked - one is the climbing, which is not anything like Tomb Raider or Uncharted. It is puzzle solving and stamina management and sometimes incredibly tense. The other thing I loved is the rarity of bullets - you get maybe a handful throughout the entire game and so you are forced into situations where you might use your single bullet to kill one enemy in the hopes it scares the hell out of the other two that were with him. It might work or it might not. You never get into firefights, you get into very intense standoffs and any hesitation on your part will get you killed.Cons? The game looks like trash, ends very suddenly and is quite liniar. It's not Fallout. But I was very impressed by the gameplay ideas the devs of I Am Alive had and it's too bad the game didn't get more critical success. I would have loved to see a sequel with a better budget.

content:
Posted: September 7, 2012
												DON'T BUY!  I know the trailer looks good.  However, this game fails on an overwhelming majority of levels.  Let's get the nice stuff out of the way: the art is good & the voice acting isn't terrible.The pacing is stilted & awkward; the camera angle feels claustrophobic and unnatural & when he's climbing it's randomly a fixed camera; the difficulty isn't challenging, it's frustrating and feels inconsistent and unfair.  The music is samey & swells with the same grating "dramatic" loop the second your stamina gets low.  And it will get low A LOT, so the music loses its meaning. Every single combat is essentially the same quick time event, but instead of "press x, then press y" it's "click the mouse button a whole lot really quickly."  Wanna run?  Clickclickclickclickclick.  Climb up a ladder?  Clickclickclickclickclick.  Open a locked gate? Clickclickclickclickclick. Fight an enemy?  Clickclickclickclickclick.  Fight more than one enemy?  Dead.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 5, 2013
												This game is good for about the first hour... then it quickly becomes apparent that NOTHING will get better. "I Am Alive" hides some serious issues underneath a beautiful atmosphere, and honestly I didn't catch them at first.Atmosphere/DesignI am a huge fan of post-apocalypic and survival games. Give me an ugly waste land, a single can of beans, and a stick and I'm in heaven. The atmosphere is probably the best thing about this game: cars are overturned and rusted from years of abandonment, buildings are crumbling with most of their windows broken out, the streets are empty, and small pockets of survivors/bandits can be seen scuttling from cover to cover. However, after awhile, I did notice some flaws. First, all bandits and survivors seem to hide out in buildings that are undergoing some kind of construction. The obvious reason for this is that construction offers a lot of pipes and ledges for you to implement the primary gameplay element of climbing/platforming. Logically, it's idiotic. The "event" that caused the apocalpse in the game has left most buildings damaged, and yet somehow these UNFINISHED buildings are left standing along with all of their scaffolding, tools, and materials intact? That's just stupid. Furthermore, EVERYTHING is gray. I get it, apocalypse= dirt covers everything, but dam, cars should still come in multiple colors at least! These two flaws combine so that every area is the same crumbling/under construction gray building, and it gets boring to look at really fast.GameplayDon't believe the trailers, this game is a climbing/platformer. I would liken it to assassins creed, but it's not as fast or intuitive as that game. The climbing in this game is SLOW, but worse than that it is also tedious. You are given a stamina meter and it runs out extremely fast, which makes sense to make it challenging, but there are several moments that are absolutely unforgiving. There are areas where you literally have to scale a building, and there is a veritable maze of pipes and ledges that you must navigate absolutely perfectly, or your stamina runs out and you fall to your death. This wouldn't be a problem if you could just look and plan a safe route, but often it's simply trial and error because you can't see where there's a ledge for you to stop and regain your stamina. To top it off there is a permanent stamina loss mechanic, where you can extend your cimbing time using up the stamina meter itself! This mechaninc is completely artificial because the devs obviously set up some climbing puzzles to require you to use it, which means you would always have failed those sections without it. The combat is also idiotic. You have a gun and a machete, but combat only occurs in two ways: a stand-off/bluff and a quick-time event. You never have more than three bullets for your gun, so when you encounter enemies you have to quickly draw on them, shoot the one who has a gun first, (or he will shoot you even while you are pointing a gun at him), and then "juggle" the other two with commands, environmental traps, and your machete. Can you swing your machete? NO. It uses a ridiculously long QTE where the enemy always blocks your attack and you have to mash the button to kill him, which gives plenty of time for his friend to run up and kill you. So you end up telling them to back up until you can kick one over a ledge, or make him step in a fire, and then kill the last one with a QTE. It was this terrible gameplay that inevitably made me put down the game. I spent an hour at one point figuring out the perfect climbing path up a building that required the least permanent loss of stamina, and after I reached the top I was immediately greeted by three enemies, who took me around 8 tries to defeat. Ultimately, just boring!StoryThis isn't really a spoiler, but you are looking for your family. Surprise, surprise, you were separated from your family after an apoclyptic event! That NEVER happens! Don't get me wrong, the "find your missing family" storyline could have been great, and even starts fairly promising with a scene at your house where you pick up a few clues as to where your family may be. I was honestly looking forward to a story where your wife left litle clues behind everywhere she went that you would follow to inch closer and closer to her. But guess what? After that first scene in your house, you NEVER look for your wife again! Sure that is your "long-term" goal, but for the duration of the this game, you are on one long side quest to help out someone else. Yep, the entire game is spent helping ONE other person that your character is not related to or knows in any way. This is reason #2 why I stopped playing, I genuinely didn't care about what my character was doing. It doesn't even make sense! You encounter like twenty life-threatening situations just for this one stranger!Technical NoteI have a very good PC and a newer AMD Radeon GPU, and I had to make some serious tweaks to my system to stop the environment from completely disappearing! I can run far Cry 4 on max settigns, but this game made me spend a few HOURS just to see the dam floor! Also, you cannot play it with anything but a gamepad. Using a keyboard and mouse make the camera stutter every 3-5 seconds and it is absolutely enfuriating.Don't buy this game, because I am confident that you will have the same experience I had. You will be really excited about the apocalyptic story and atmosphere, and you will be wooed for the first couple of hours, until you start to smell something, and then the smell will grow and grow until it makes you stop playing. Later the next day you will realize the smell was coming from the sh!t this game is made of.

content:
Posted: April 22, 2014
												Before reading my review, first thing you need to do is watch the E3 trailer from 2008.


YouTube™ Video: E32008 - Ubisoft I Am Alive Trailer 

			Views: 3,038,278		

			Brand new title by Ubisoft unveiled at E3 2008.		

Did you watch it? Looks great right? I remember E3 2008 and said to myself, "This game looks great!", although I knew it was a cinematic trailer, it was the initial concept of survival and escape from hordes of other humans that were possibly your friends prior to "The Event", as it's called in the published version of the game, that stood out to me.The game we got? Well, it went through a lot of changes as it was already in development for like, five years prior to E3 2008, and then released in 2012, went through even more changes. The biggest change is that you don't experience "The Event", okay, it's a big f*cking earthquake. But how awesome would it have been to experience that as part of the game?Instead, I Am Alive takes place a year later as your character returns to the city of Haventon to find his wife and daughter, how original. Instead, you find some girl named Mei who's just crying in the playground by your house, so you help her find her mother instead, as well as some bloke in a wheelchair.During the game, you can help strangers that actually need it, or kill people that are hostile. It's a very black and white game, literally too. Instead of the nice, yet muddy, colors of the initial trailer, Ubisoft Shanghai rapes your eyes with an over abundance of black and white, mostly white, film grain. The dust is thick, foggy thick.Let me remind you that this game came out in 2012. The textures and models from Super Mario Sunshine are better, and that was 2002. The gameplay tries to emulate the Assassin's Creed climbing, but somehow messes that up. And the shooting mechanic switches you from 3rd person survival game, to 1st person shooter.This game's just doesn't really do anything right, except for the limited ammo which would make sense considering the stuff doesn't just appear out of nowhere.It's mediocre.5/10

content:
Posted: May 18, 2013
												I will start this by stating that it's a decent game.  I found it to be extremely easy, but it's a decent game nonetheless.  However, these are some key issue that I would like to point out.  The main issue is that there is almost no back story.  I know, people will think 'but there has to be, even a little.'  Well, there is a little, but it is only learned through playing the early stages.  Other than that, however, there is no general narrative that sums up the state of the world at or before the time of the game.  Now, this isn't to say it's a horrible game.  It is interesting, but it's more like a demo of plausible video game features, rather than an actual game.  I would also say that it's fairly short.  Even when you are trying to achieve all of the in-game mini quests, it's still short.Unless it's on sale, I do not recommend purchase.  4/10

content:
Posted: November 25, 2012
												Without giving anything away, let me just say that I Am Alive is incredibly depressing. I'm not talking about the story, which is half baked and clearly cuts off well before whatever script the developers were working off of ended. I'm talking about the fact that every single moment of the game was spent remembering how excited I was after the first trailer came out, promising an open world exploration that never ended. Instead, the final product was this♥♥♥♥♥♥ The game gets repetitive after the first level, and nothing actually happens. There is no open world, just some ♥♥♥♥♥♥ unfulfilling side missions that were clearly tacked on in a desperate attempt to make the game seem deep.I do like the almost but not quite monochrome stylings of the graphics, they addded a nice touch to the ambiguously post-apocalyptic wasteland that I barely got to properly explore.At some point it became necessary for the player character, whose name I already forgot, to lash a young girl to his backpack and ♥♥♥♥ around sheer walls for a while. This was very annoying...To repeat my previous point, I am Alive was originally meant to be a massive adventure through a broken world, like S.T.A.L.K.E.R. with platforming elements.The last thing I need is a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ plot device hooked to my character, constantly reminding me of how good this game would have been if it hadn't hit so many problems during development.The main character dies at the end, you don't find out why. Presumably, somewhere between the end of the game and the credits, he went on aforementioned huge exciting journey without the player.Don't buy this game. Ubisoft needs to go back and try making this game a second time, perhaps actually making the game they said they were making the first time around.

content:
Posted: August 23, 2016
												7/10Pros- Atmospheric- Great storyline- Excellent tension the entire game- Very Difficult in a good way- Intersting combat system (Every fight is more of a puzzle than a shooter)- Great platforming- Beautiful map- Open world elements- For its time, it had decent graphicsCons- Ending was terrible- Though they were decent for the time, the graphics are dated and can be a little annoying at first- No warning before the end- No Steam AchievementsThis was a pleasant experience that was worth $15. It would be best to get this game on sale unless you are just wanting a difficult platformer/survival game right away. I would have liked for them to have finished the plot and their ending was absolutely one of the worst in game history, but it at least fills in some gaps when you actually think about it. I just want to say that the tension that I felt in this game was tremendous. I felt weak and like I had to think to survive. Exploration always payed off in the beginning, but eventually the fear of tough enemies that could be around any corner kept me from exploring what really could have been explored. There are some very gruesome and raw scenes in this game and would highly recommend that nothing less than a mature audience play it. Seriously, there is some jacked up stuff. It was unique though and I really enjoyed the experience. It did take me an hour or so to really get into it though, so if you buy it, keep playing. It gets better. I beat this game first time on Survival and if you want a real challenge, I suggest you do the same. Spoilers incoming! Please do not read this unless you don't want the game or have already beaten it. The event is never explained and this bugs me. I really want to know what happened and what is going on. There are too many holes left in the storyline. However, the ending is what really bugged me at first. It was just too sudden and felt like they ran out of money to finish the game, but that being said, I believe that he is indeed alive. The end where his wife is crying as she watches the account of his travels does not mean he is dead. Seeing that would be a very emotional experience. Imagine seeing a documentary of your wife (or husband) trying to find you for a year and you see how much heck she/he went through and how she/he never gave up on finding you and finally did. It would be emotional (especially for those of us in the steam community who still have emotions). His stuff is everywhere so he made it there. All of his stuff was not given to her by a good samaritan. He is there. This ending definitely leaves the door open for a number two and we can only hope that they retain the great things of this game, improve the flaws, and make it sooner rather than later. Thanks for reading the review. Peace

number of helpful: 24 of 45 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 21, 2014
												Lets start with the good things as there are few.1. The levels itself - are in itself atmospheric, it really gives you the impression how a town could look like after a series of earthquakes.2. The climbing mechanic - that you loose endurance/stamina if you climb is a nice change.3. Overall interesting take on survival in a town after a global catastrophic event - without the obligatory zombies.Yeah...that's it.Now to go on with the bad things where do I start:The graphics are washed up and even if you use the highest settings you can't change the fact that this piece of crap was meant to be played on an XBOX or PS2. Yes I know - it is developed for the XBOX 360 and PS3 but I can't drop the feeling that I have seen better graphics in part on a XBOX or PS2.The music at the beginning is good and adds to the little bit of atmosphere there is at all - but it gets so repetitive after a time (especially as you loose stamina constantly and with you loosing stamina the music builds up and always the same tune) that you sometimes just want to mute the whole game.So now we know that the game itself is just a common stone between pearls and diamonds in terms of audio and graphics, but there are these rare jewels that suck at this too but still have great gameplay and story.This game is absolutely NOT one of them.The gameplay is overall horrific with the exception of the climbing mechanic.Combat or stealth - it gives you no choice - you have to fight. There is no sneaking (although they implemeted the sneak button how cool is that) at all, the moment you pass a certain point the game spawns enemies and you can not get around them either because they detect you on the spot or you desperately try to get by the ones that are already somewhere in the level - and the level is created so that you have to get through them. This is no "THIEF" at all. So lets "fight" which comes down to coerce the AI in getting stuck or other "special" movements.Why? Because you either have guns - for which you practically never have any ammunition or you can use your mighty machete.Nonono, not hacking and slashing, you have to wait until your enemies have reached you and then you can draw your machete for one hit.If it is someone with a machete he will block it and you have to go through button smashing, it is easier if the enemy has a gun, then no button smashing.The only problem is that these guys come in packs. So the moment you have to buttonsmash and are locked in the scripted killscene, our enemies friends are hacking you to pieces OR his gun equipped buddies just kill you with one shot (ok,ok @ higher difficulty)The AI can shoot at you forever but if you loot them they magically have emptied everything they had after 1001 shots (one of the many bugs in this game shows you that fact when you get stuck somewhere in a wall and they use you as invincible target practice or you just run around eating up your health items just to see how often they can fire) if you are lucky there is one bullet left after you killed them, about 50% of the time the gun is empty although the owner of it WILL kill you with it if you believe that you could reload the level and just walk past by him.Yes I have the feeling that the people working at this game desperately wanted to shoot themeselves after they saw what they had created and implemented this thoughtful underlying message of the last bullet.You can get a shotgun in the game but first you really have to do some climbing and exploring and the few shots you have are the only ones in the whole game.After around 75% of the game you get a bow with one arrow - oh and you won't believe it - YES!! you can reuse that arrow. The story is pretty mediocre, you should have encountered it somewhere else already and probably better told but worst of all it is pretty shortlived (around 8 hours and I took my sweet time) and cut at the end.The ending is one bad joke. I couldn't help but think that at some point of production they really believed they had born a new superloved AAA title hence the dream of producing dlcs and a second game.But when at the end they realized what a boring abomination they helped to bring into this gamingworld they just hurried up and forced some kind of ending in and a really bad one too.  The bottom line is that if you really want to try out this game buy it in a Steam Sale...for up to 3 $/€. Anything more will make you wish you had tossed that money in a blender and watched it blend - more entertainment for the buck.
