number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 8, 2014
												First off, I would like to state that I have yet to complete this game out of sheer frustration.Though I will keep on attempting to finish the game,granted if I can win the race between me finishing the game and my controller breaking.That being said, here are my two cents about this game.I will start off with the bad side of the game in order to create a critique that feels like you are eating a pudding with glazed sugar layered at the bottom, where the further you go and eat in more of the chunks, the sweeter it gets.I Am Alive was once an extremely anticipated game when it was first leaked on 2009, and announced to be completed on 2010, but was later pushed back several times before finally being released on 2012. This gave potential buyers the time to ponder about the game.When news first befell unto my ears, I heard so many rumors that this game would become the ultimate open world survival game with a good storyline to follow through. However, like any fairly hyped games, you are bound to be disappointed.The final product released into the market looked like a stillbirth compared to what people were expecting from the game.As a result, the game's popularity sank faster than a fat lady trying to water skii whilst wearing lead shoes.Granted, this is not entirely the developers' fault, as speculations may have created greater expectation, but could be easily diminished by not being so hush about the game's situation and deliver actual information and updates rather than popping up ever so often just to deliver push-backs.Over the course of some five hours of me playing this game, I can sum up the game in three words, "Trial and error."By using new players' naiveté, the game would constantly throw you into situations where you are required to know beforehand what you are facing, to which usually results in death, and because of the limited retry system, this is like someone giving you a slap in the face and then proceeded to light your head on fire, as the system adds more than a big slap to the face, to which I will elaborate in a moment. I have found myself setting the game to the easiest difficulty to allow myself to go through all the death hoops the game presents to me with my trial and error technique in order to become acquainted with said death hoops, just so I would not light myself on fire on the normal playthrough.The second thing is the delusion of difficulty, not illusion, but delusion. For some reason, the developer thought that simply by limiting the amount of retries the player can have in a trial and error game, the game would be interesting and challenging. If that were the case, then Honey Boo Boo's mother is a supermodel, and telling people to limit the amount of times they can urinate a day is a good idea.Look, we have all gone through the age where that formula worked, where you played, died, and subsequently receive a game over screen. That was when the existing technology limited the amount of content that could be present in the game, and so by using that retry formula, the consumers would have the illusion of getting their money's worth. I have had my fair share of Contra and Ghouls 'n Ghosts already back in the days, I want to be able to play a game that would not tell me how many times I could go pee-pee in the waterbowl.The three things I also absolutely hated in this game are: The grappling hook mechanic, the death conditions, and the bullet scarcity formula. When I first acquired the grappling hook, it was a complete nightmare for me. The swining momentum is just so bad that it makes swimming through a tub full of mayonaise seem that much easier. It took me seven tries before I could finally get the gist of it and finally not fall off and become the next cannibal's grand slam. Talking about falling and dying a horrible death, I never understood how the main character sometimes manages to die from a half-meter drop. Those areas obviously have absolutely nothing there, and if I were sliding, my momentum was just about enough to rub a gum off of my shoe, but yet, those spots still somehow manage to kill me. Perhaps messing up the sliding gave the main character so much emotional distress that he died of pure embarrassment.Within any survival games, I am one of those players that tend to hoard anything that I can find and use as little of them as possible, this game was no exception, but what definitely has gotten to me was the fact that the game will attempt to, in any manner and time as physically possible, to keep your bullet count around one or two. Now, this may sound like an excellent mechanic, and I am the one who is whining about something mundane, but the fact that any time you kill a gun-wielding assailant with two or more bullets in your possession, the gun you get from them is always empty, really ticks me off. However, if some other baddie picks up the gun, he would start shooting up the place like a twelve year old kid playing Rookie Mode on Resident Evil 2. This is not a good mechanic, this only manages to show the player a huge sign written thusly, "You are in my pistol theme park, and you will never have more bullets than I want you to." Why bother doing the whole survival aspect when you are not letting me worry about using resources? Since I know for a fact that I will always get bullets somewhere for a necessary fight ahead of me.Talking about bullets and fights, the staticity and linearity is absolutely flabbergasting. You would think that despite not being the ultimate open world survival game, I Am Alive would still provide the fundementals of the genre, right?Wrong.For the majortiy, if not all, of the cases, there is only one way to climb to the destination, only one way to swing somewhere with the swing hook, and only one way to defeat foes. There are some hidden items here and there given out for looking a bit further, but would also usually mean wasting precious foodstuffs and dying; they might as well place big pieces of paper with, "I owe you, invalid upon death," all over it, as this was mentioned to be a trial and error game with limited tries. As for its staticity, every event and item placement are always at exactly the same place, even with static events, you would at least expect non-static placements for loots, and hope that perhaps that one time when you recheck that mundane corner again, a flashing item surrounded by an white aura would appear, like a young kid hoping to find Narnia in their grandmother's wardrobe, only to find an abundent amount of mothballs located within.Oh, and the save system sucks harder than an industrial grade vacuum cleaner.Despite so many factors, including the menu being complete and utter stinking fecal matter, that make this game so frustrating, I cannot get myself to hate this game.All in all, I am just so very intrigued by the world, the environment, and the idea of this game.Despite the frustration I Am Alive makes me deal with, during the immersive moments of the game, when I truly looked, especially into the story and the world, this game makes me feel in awe, and delivers so many other emotional impacts, like a pyromaniac seeing a forest on fire for the first time (to which the aforementioned person may or may not have been the cause of).I realize that I am on my own in the broken world.I realize that this game is not be for everyone, hence I would not recommend this game.However, if you are willing to overlook the many flaws I have already pointed out, and the ones I may have forgotten about, go ahead and try it out, but I do not in any way guarentee a frustration-free playthrough.TL;DR:You most likely will not like it, but if you are willing to look at the game in a different perspective, by all means, go for it.

content:
Posted: November 3, 2014
												I really wanted to give this game a try, but it seems to be fighting back.There is NO FOV SETTING in the game, so if you tend to suffer from motion sickness induced by low FOV, this is not your game. There are hacks available, though. On the plus side, the game does not appear to have motion blur.There are several issues with the game, such as the controls not remappable separately, but only as a group (e.g. "Drop/Draw Weapon"). And since "Fire" and "Run" are in the same group, that is really annoying.Another issue (and ultimately the one that leads me to not recommending the game) is that the game streams in world data, and when it does that, it sometimes stops responding to mouse input. This can go away within moments, but on occasion it stays. As a result, your mouse cursor will be fixed to the centre of the screen, in menus as well as in Windows when tabbed out. Even killing the game process doesn't seem to fix it, only a system reboot will do.I tried to like the game, but it's just not enjoyable.

												This game took a couple of hours to really get used to.  The story is essentially about a man working his way back to his family after a catastrophe.  The colors are really, super bland (expected, I guess for the setting), but what took the most getting used to were the controls, they felt delayed (maybe it was me?).  I did enjoy some of the platforming-ish type puzzles to solve.  Because of the rarity of ammo, weapon combat could get intense and I never really got the hang of melee.  The dust mechanic was kind of cool (loss of stamina until you reached fresh air), but it wasnt enough to hook me.I suppose my whole feelings on the game could be summed up with this statement, "I spent more time wishing for it to end than was spent enjoying it."

Posted: February 23, 2014
												The gameplay is fantastic. The freerunning aspects are relatively realistic and fun. The fast paced tactical decisions in combat are difficult to get used to but rewarding when you beat them after about the fifth reload, assuming you don't mind retrys being a significant portion of your playtime. That said, the game uses a horrible retry system where you find the right to reload a save like a power up, and if you run out, it sends you to the begining of the level.  Had an amazing amount of potential, but appeared painfully unfinished. I tore through most of the game in four hours, then spent most of the next day looking forward to finishing it. When I did, there was only about 20 minutes of content left and I was left without closeure to the story and a lot of massive disappointment.    When the game ended it even presented me with a stat board full of trackings of things that were never even an option in the playthrough. The game is clearly an abandoned project and in its current state is too short to be worth getting into.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 26, 2014
												This game has a lot of flaws, but it still manages to create a unique experience unlike anything you've ever played.Unlike most post-apocalyptic games, you don't have any zombies or monsters to fight. Your biggest enemies are the environment, the lack of resources and the other survivors.Getting places is hard. Roads are blocked and bridges are broken, and your climbing skills are the only thing keeping you alive. Problem is, you have a very limited amount of stamina that drains every time you climb or run, and when it's drained fully - you fall. As if that's not enough, dust storms make the air outside unbreathable, and when inside the fog your stamina will constantly drain until you die, or reach high ground.Resources are very limited, and you will rarely have more than 2-3 bullets in your gun. You will often have none. Combat is not based on who shoots faster, but on psychology and bluffing. Raise your hands to let the enemy come near enough for a surprise attack, or aim your empty pistol at him and tell him to back off up to a cliff, then push him over.This combat system makes you get very creative when fighting 5-6 enemies, since you probably wont have enough bullets to kill them all.Some survivors will only fight you if you get too close, and backing off will prevent a fight. Others will ask for your help, and you will have to choose wether or not to spare your very limited supplies.With this combat system and the constant pressure of the draining stamina, this game keeps you stressed throughout it all. And as if that's not enough - you have a limited number of retries before having to restart from the beginning of the chapter!The game is flawed, though:Controls can be a bit clunky while climbing, sometimes resulting in a pointless death and waste of retry.It's not always clear where to go, especially in heavy dust where you can't see♥♥♥♥♥♥ and you might end up walking in circles trying to find the entrance to a building, and it can get quite frustrating.The story is very lacking. You learn pracitcally nothing about what actually happened and the story just seems to stop rather than end when you finish the game. While the game is semi-openworld, you have little to no motivation to explore. Yeah, you might find other survivors or some food and water, but is it really worth running around in a dust storm for?Overall, this game is a solid 8/10 and I highly recommend playing it.

content:
Posted: September 18, 2012
												Despite reading mixed reviews of this game I was surprised it was actually this good. The world has been struck by earthquakes and it's up to you, a survivor, to try and find your family. The graphics are dark and moody; you can only see a few metres ahead which makes it difficult to differentiate friend from foe. It really adds to the tension. That, and the lack of bullets. You have to pick targets carefully, and even decide if you want to kill them. It's not always needed, you see, and you really need to preserve your ammo.There are also other survivors to be found and they might need your help. It's up to you. Helping them will grant you a retry. So in the event that you are killed you'll be able to try it again. Besides killing and helping people you'll be climbing around like the PoP and AC games, which feels natural by now, and is cool.Too bad the game is a bit short; it will take most people around 4-6 hours to complete. Yet another game that has to be experienced, people.[Rating: 81/100]

number of helpful: 10 of 18 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 3, 2014
												If you're a fan of post-apocalyptic games then this is a must have. You play as a survivor of the apocalypse searching the forgotten city to find your family. This game shows quite a realistic view of what it would be like in an apocalypse with it's dark atmosphere, having to scavenge for food, ammo and survivors. I Am Alive is very similar to The Last of Us in many ways as they are both post-apocalyptic survival games. The combat in I Am Alive has a more strategic approach as you have to take in the amount of ammo and health you have, also whether the enemies have a gun or a machete or even armour. Also what was awesome was how you're able to use the environment to kill an enemy, e.g. Holding your gun out to an enemy who has only but a machete and forcing him to walk back into a fire or off a cliff.The overall gameplay gives you more of a restricted feel as you can't explore a lot of the areas and a lot is just blocked off. One thing that got my frustrated a lot was the camera view. Not being able to kill the right enemies due to slight knock of your mouse can really be frustrating. Another thing I didn't like was the amount of climbing you have to do as it just got repetitive and became a hassle.The game only took about 4-4.5 hours to complete and so in conclusion, yes I'd highly recommend this game if it's on sale and you enjoy survival horror and post-apocalyptic games.

number of helpful: 10 of 18 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 31, 2014
												I found this game to be very enjoyable. I really liked the atmosphere, I thought the story was satisfying for a while but by the end I was left wanting just a little more, and I thought the environment was beautifully crafted. I do think this game could've used a little more color, though.This isn't the best game around, but I like it. I think it's worth the price that it currently sells for. If you are in need of an interesting singleplayer game to play, try this one. I thought the "intimidation" feature where you can scare off enemies by just pointing a gun at them even if its not loaded was pretty cool and original. Climbing in this game can be fun. This game is really just full of unique features that you won't find in most other games of the post-apocalyptic survival category.Other notes: the graphics are just good; not excellent, not average, but just good. The sounds reinforce the game's atmosphere pretty well. The AI can be tough to deal with at times. The level design itself is a puzzle at times.Again, if you are looking for an interesting post-apocalyptic singleplayer game to play, this could be the game for you. If you want something more action oriented or roleplay-ish, you might want to skip this one. This game gets a 7/10 from me.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2013
												I Am Alive? More like I Am Alpha!Because it's a clearly rushed product that's not very well optimized, is ugly, is short as hell and ends strangely and abruptly.It's also one of the best B-games I've ever played.I Am Alive drops you into a world torn asunder by a cataclysmic event. You're just a guy looking for people from his past, trying to help those in need, and trying to survive in a harsh reality where everything's out to get you. Your main ability is climbing, and the climbing system of IAA is really well-done: it controls a lot like Uncharted or Tomb Raider, but with the addition of a Stamina system: the longer you climb, the more your bar depletes. If it gets to the end, you'll still be able to climb, but your maximum stamina capacity will slowly dwindle until you get to a resting spot. You can restore your max stamina with items, but it's a neat take on providing urgency to a system that's been used before. The combat is the second tier of the game, and it's also exceptionally well-done: the game utilizes an Intimidation system, which allows you to bluff your opponents using an empty gun while you try to control fights to your favor. Sometimes they'll call your bluff, and you'll have to either shoot them or go for a machete kill; other times, you might want to approach hostiles unarmed, wait for one to get close, and then attack with your machete, surprising everyone and giving you the upper hand. Ammo is scarce, and you don't want to waste a bullet: chances are if you miss a shot, you're about to die. The guns feel good, and the fact that unarmored foes die in one hit is an absolutely incredible way of finally adding realistic gunplay, which makes every encounter memorable. If you come across guys with guns, you either need to be unarmed and hope they come to search you or shoot them first. You will probably die a few times before you get the hang of things, and enemies flanking you might surprise you. You later get a bow, which leads to interesting combat encounters since arrows are recoverable and the bow is silent.The story, largely, is told by victims you save and the few friendly people you encounter on your journey and is well-written. The dynamic you have with the first friendly character you meet is the best, leading you to develop an emotional attachment to them. It's not going to win any awards, but it certainly helps to keep you motivated. The game's not without its flaws, however; the ending is rushed, unsatisfying, and leaves you with a lot of questions, and there are times when the checkpoint system can get very annoying. I played the game on Normal and it was pretty tough, but I never had to restart a chapter. There are segments where you wander aimlessly through the streets, hoping to find something climbable to either save you from the dust storms or lead you to the next destination. The game is also (not, in my eyes, a negative) very short (I clocked in at 4h059s) which could leave some people thinking they overpaid. I really liked my time within I Am Alive's world, and a fully-developed sequel or spin-off in the same world would be more than welcome. 8/10 Bows and Bullets

content:
Posted: May 20, 2014
												I first played this game right after reading The Road by Cormac McCarthy (which I recommend), and thus was recently exposed to a silent, vast, and depressing take on post-apocalyptic stories. Yet when I started this game up, I immediately got♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off at the main character for running his damn mouth off the entire time. "Hey, I should climb up this bridge." "Ah, I almost fell into that huge chasm!" "I should avoid that scary looking guy whose visual cues are saying the same things that I am right now." In the first 20 minutes of the game that I played, there was more monologing than the entirety of The Road, in which there were 200% more main characters. Maybe I just had my expectations up too high, but I believe that a setting like the one in this game should attempt to be truthful to what it intends to be instead of just a reskinning of Uncharted.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8
												This is a great game with a great idea behind it. However, its main downfall is its incompatibility issues with the modern operating systems to date. I've had it crash on me multiple times and luckily, I was on a checkpoint that was fairly close to where I originally was prior to the crash. However, the latest crash had me set back so far. This game has so much potential for those who can actually play it without any probability of a crash. Any way, aside from me bashing on this game's compatibility issues, it is a great game. It requires you to make use of your resources and to not make haste when faced with a potentially deadly situation. Ammunition is extremely hard to come by and killing someone with a machete isn't so easy. I enjoy that sense of tediousness to figure out which opponent actually deserves a bullet and thereafter, eliminate the other opposing threats. The concept of oxygen preservation seems extremely accurate and realistic in areas that contain a thicker volumity to its atmosphere. All in all -- great story, fair graphics, fair game. Just be advised that crashes will exist if you're on a more modern operating system.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 27, 2012
												Two apocalyptic game reviews from me tonight. I'm in the reviewing mood:)Anyway first up is 'I am Alive' where a series of mega 'quakes has pretty much ruined everything. And your task is to seek your wife and child in your now destroyed home city, in 3rd person. The story and acting are nothing special but passable so we'll move on from there.The ruined city is well designed and looks as you would expect a city to look after a huge earthquake. It's bleak and dusty, and crumbly.. and as you can imagine you have to travel over and under it. At times having to scale whats left of huge skyscrapers which gives a great sense of height as you scramble from ledge to ledge. The setting and soundtrack give an excellent apocalypic feel. It feels bleak and depressing,It plays ok, but the combat is a bit clumsy. But you get used to it. And not everyone wants to kill you. Whether you help them all depends on what you are willing to sacrifice. It's not as linear as it seems either.Recommended!

content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												THIS GAME...I Am Alive could've been a better game, good story, and like all the people who watched the trailers and got excited or at least interested, good trailers (?)- Your character doesn't stand out ( i can't even remember if he had a name or not...)- The controls are pretty bad, sometimes hiking is a pain, sometimes fighting is a pain...and you even get stages and places where you don't have the slightest clue about what to do, because nothing works!- same animations for kills, if stabbed someone, you know you're gonna stab everyone pretty much that way, same for the others weapons, you got about 3 enemies renders that got Crtl+c/v all over the place, except minors changes, like you got guy_1 with other hat, or other clothes, sometimes the even say the same stuff- You get side missions from a lot of vagabons dudes ( i remember helping only one guy!, all the children and women needs you, all the guy turn into rejected-borderlands 2 psychos!), but they usually take a lot of time you don't want to spend on this ( i can't remember how long i spent getting a pack of cigarretes for the old guy)- You get lost. a lot. they got one block and copied all over the city!, there are some buildings that you can tell apart, BUT.Anyway...something good about the game?, i dunno, the ending kinda gave me a surprise, but get this game when it is on sale...the game could've been better, but it was poor-delivered and repetitiveBONUS FOR THE EFIALTES-BASKET CASE-LIKE-MAN THAT GIVES YOU THE SHOTGUN ( there is no ammo for it on the game, you got 2 or 4 rounds then forget it!), oh, of course, you got to run a lot of errands for him first.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 19, 2013
												I found myself quite impressed with what Ubisoft Shanghai managed to ship out of this project. Negatively, the story and voice acting are subpar and some of the gameplay mechanics get repetitive. However, outside of those quirks I was actually really engrossed by the game; the morality mechanics are interesting, the climbing is tense as hell, and the atmosphere is convicing for such a small game. For $15 it's a good price because it encourages replaying the whole game to beat previous scores, and during a sale it's definitely worthwhile to buy.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												It's not necessarily a great game but an interesting take on a third-person climber/survival set in a post-apocalyptic fictional city. There's not much I can say.The story is generic but there are some interesting gameplay mechanics. You can use a gun (even if the clips are empty) to threaten and instill fear among hostile survivors and either choose to loot or kill them, or potentially leaving them alone. But I saw repetitive it's gotten.But let's look back at the game's history. From what I remember, I am Alive was announced in e3 2008 (or 2009). It was shown with a CGI trailer. At the time, I thought this was gonna be a game similar to The Last of Us but I am Alive was delayed for so long. When it finally came out, we got this.The current I am Alive which is on steam and other platforms was released as a downloable only title. So it never became a full retail game as originally promised.

content:
Posted: September 16, 2013
												It's okay I guess. The whole point of the game is to figure out exactly the right way to interact with an environment that appears very complex but actually is simplified and abstracted to "balance" the "strategy" of picking which thing to do at a given time. I shouldn't have to say how frustrating it is that you can't climb over diagonal surfaces or rubble in a game that has such a sophisticated vertical climbing dynamic. For example, you might have to climb over the 100-ft high superstructure of a highway overpass at one point because you can't simply step up on the hood of a car. Shrug.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18, 2014
												This game is not very alive.Ever had a project starting with a good idea, and you never get far with it. One day you return to it and you can't get in sync with what you had in mind. That sort of thing is what this game feels like.Atleast I can say the premise and idea is good, but I really can't figure out anything else good to say.All characters are flat because the game is infatuated with setpieces (I hope you like grey!) and trying to force emotions and exposition onto the player. I find an older man coughing that needs an inhaler, and I move on since I don't have one. Logic tells me there's one close by and as I move on the man says "I guess you want to help me but just can't yet". There's no understanding of immersive dialogue here. When I get him the inhaler he starts to spout exposition like everything in the game seems to want to. "Lemme guess, you wanna know more about the event right?" No I'm looking for medicine.The very flow of the way everything comes at you is so unnatural. It feels like someone wrote a story that won't work so it was half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥into a game. Heck there's enough hipsters in gaming that some would say it's well done.It's like someone makes a little game and tells you to try it and say you can explore on your own. Although the moment you go left where they'd prepared an event to the right, the guy rips the controller from your hands and says, "oh no no, you don't want that. Look over here is something cool"... In my exploring the game literally gave me a prompt "You weren't supposed to go this way, turn back." Gees.. let me just look around.From the very beginning the camera is a problem and game has tons of technical issues. Every gameplay aspect is so on rails, rinse and repeat.This game was looking interesting when announced way back, but it went through a lot of reworking and it's easy to see it's become a leather faced abomination. Everything game-like is lacking and drowning in the game's pretentiousness.I'd say i've already said too much about this game, when there's not much worth mentioning. I Am Alive is incredibly pretentious and poorly designed, executed and unfinished. The end.I don't enjoy slamming a game when it's gifted to me, but at the end of the day I gotta be honest.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 9, 2013
												Sort of slow-paced thriller game.  The combat is weak, but it's an interesting spin on the usual mash-up of 'shooter' games.  You have to choose whether to run, shoot, stealth, or try to muscle out the fights.  Ammo is SO incredibly hard to find that it really makes you think about having a game plan before you just run in guns blazing.  But the combat is not why you play this game.  The environmental exploration, navigation, and stamina climbing are exhilirating.  Many times you're climbing hundreds of feet above the city streets, your stamina is inching closer to empty and you're putting forth max effort just to hang on before falling to your death.  That's where the game's strength appears.  The music and hud elements really get your heart pumping as you make quick decisions in this post-apocalyptic city.  Finally the element of helping various people around the city:  do you risk giving up your well-earned supplies to help out those around you in need, or will you need that when you're dangling hundreds of feet in the air and on your last breaths?  Overall 5/10

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 21, 2014
												This game is brilliant. The depth and immersion of this game is unbelievable. There's no zombies. No irradiated monsters. Nothing like that. There's just people. And they act like people. Some just want to defend their home. Others want your stuff. The way you fight is fantastic as well. You fight with psychology, rather than your muscles. You'll almost always be outnumbered. You almost always won't have any ammo. Use your mind, surprise the bandits, and make them -think- that you have a bullet chambered in that pistol you're pointing at them. If you go in, gun up, you'll find yourself dead before you can even -try- and threaten them.Overall, you'll hardly ever see the ruined city you're in. You'll barely be able to see a few feet in any direction. But then you'll climb up and out of the dust, and the world will just open up before your eyes.One downside though, is it can occasionally go a little funny with the controls. This is a game where at times, it's quite plain that it's a port. But the slight irking from having your character shimmy along a ledge to the right, rather than climbing further up a building, is quite easily forgiven once you take everything else into stock.I'd heartily recommend this game to anyone who is fond of the survivor Post-Apocalyptia genre, with a heavy emphasis on realism when it comes to combat and exploration.9.5/10

Though there is rarely a clear path, the game gives you a pently for going the wrong way with characters say annoying things over and over, or invisable walls pushing back the direction you came. The story and animations is also poorly written, and for a protangist that has a little girl, he treats this one he gets like a stray dog. Honestly, overall underwelming and boring after the first 30 mins.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 7, 2013
												6/10As I started playing this the athmosphere seemed like another one of endless "survive zombie apocalypse" games. I didn't know much what is game about because I got it as a gift from dear friend. But after a few minutes it become clear that this is not generic zombie game. It does have an apocalypse element and though clues are given about what coused it the emphasis of the story isn't on that. The game nicely combines platform and a bit of puzzle elements with survive mode. You play as a very capable and  determent character who is out to find his family in a city that suffered cataststrophe a year ago. In the process you encounter other people, some friendly, some in need of your help and some that catastrophe drowe to crime and even canibalism.  You  are given some free  will and some of  your  actions will determin fate of others but all in all it is a pretty linear game that is focused on a protagonist story. General problems with the game is its lenght which is way too short for a game of that price, lack of free will in full degree and some very annoying bugs. Also save system is terrible. It is an interested play to kill few hours but far from perfect game.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2012
												I am Alive is a realistic survival game. it looks like an adventurish action the way you control it, but your moves are always puzzling around how to survive.Please take under consideration that this is a really old game although it was out just recently. This title was being developed ever since 2003 but it was frozen due to lack of founding until ubisoft took it up.This said, the game is old. Which can be seen in various ways.Let's take this in parts.The grahics of the game are nicely designed. The engine's abilities remind of 09s to 10s games. So it's not bad at all.The environment is stanning IMO. You find yourself in a world that has ended. Nature's gone crazy. There are asphyxiating sandstorms all over and the element of dust and fog is everywhere.The dusty environment results into a vast way too back&white-ish area.Buildings, streets, inner environments too, they are all so dusty that you are actually staying in a literally desert colored city.There are meny nice ideas on the table. Earthquakes, fallen aircrafts, meta-apocalyptic views, half fallen skyscrapers, also nice places to hide, some nice areas to visit.My only one complainment from this part is that although my rig was enough to support the game, i had some rendering issues making my mouse view laggy without seeing the fps dropping (weird) GameplayI found the gameplay to be really really interesting, and actually the main reason I loved it.Realism. The whole time you are racing against the odds of running out of stamina. Climbing buildings with bare hands and walking through the sandstorm forces you to keep finding places to rest yoru stamina for some seconds or else you'll die.Also you have to keep scavenging to find canned food, water bottles, meds and a few more stuff. If played smart enough you won't have serious problems, though youw ill feel the challenge if it.Also guns. realistic circumstances as well. You start with a handgun and you barelly find bullets around. Your average ammo cap is goign to be around 2 shots. Most of the time you will use the gun to bluff against bandits and looters. A machine is going to be your main weapon, and a bow with only one arrow which can be retreaved from yoru victims. Also there's an unlockable shotgun when helping a survivor.The game really gives you ideas of things that could had been implemented. I am forgiving because of teh age of the game. Lots of elements could add to teh fun like more stealthy skills and attacks or using traps. This could have been one of the best surival games ever for me. StoryNow this is a dissapoiting part. Story is that you are just a guy surviving trying to find his wife and kid. The plot is that you end up helping a woman and her daughter find their way to safety. and stuff.Your main missions are like 3 or 4. Nothing else.The game was clearly cut off most of its material and concept. You can see that it's too incomplete. AverageThis is a pure example of taking a super awesome creation, and ♥♥♥♥ing its brains out due to producer lack of founding.The game could have been one of the most awesome titles of its kind, and it ended up being short, lacking story, and probably cut off most of its original elements ending up in a low priced easy to forget game.I feel really really sad for those who put teh efford to create the idea and start implementing it, at a time when meta-apocalyptic games were not even that mainstream at all, and then see their dream ending up as a scrap work put out for sale almost 10 ♥♥♥♥ing years later.I hope ubisoft decides to make a sequel or a prequel. Because the base of this thing right here has potential to give a much greater than average future creation.

Lots of elements could add to teh fun like more stealthy skills and attacks or using traps. This could have been one of the best surival games ever for me. StoryNow this is a dissapoiting part. Story is that you are just a guy surviving trying to find his wife and kid. The plot is that you end up helping a woman and her daughter find their way to safety. and stuff.Your main missions are like 3 or 4. Nothing else.The game was clearly cut off most of its material and concept. You can see that it's too incomplete. AverageThis is a pure example of taking a super awesome creation, and ♥♥♥♥ing its brains out due to producer lack of founding.The game could have been one of the most awesome titles of its kind, and it ended up being short, lacking story, and probably cut off most of its original elements ending up in a low priced easy to forget game.I feel really really sad for those who put teh efford to create the idea and start implementing it, at a time when meta-apocalyptic games were not even that mainstream at all, and then see their dream ending up as a scrap work put out for sale almost 10 ♥♥♥♥ing years later.I hope ubisoft decides to make a sequel or a prequel. Because the base of this thing right here has potential to give a much greater than average future creation.

content:

												This game was great. I loved the post apocolyptic atmoshere that is created by the dust filled air and crumbling cityscape. Everything feels like it's going to fall apart around you. Seeing other people is terrifying as you don't know what they will do. Or if you can fight them off. Even if your gun is out of ammo you can bluff and point it at people and they will back away from you. Climbing a huge part of the gameplay and it is great. The only thing I di not like was the ending. It was just so suden as if they just stopped writing and attempted to create an ending which felt really unsatisfying. I really wanted to know more about what was going to happen in this world. In colnclusion, I Am Alive is a very decent game and short game. It had all the right ideas but it just did not deliver a conlcusive ending.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18, 2014
												This game is not very alive.Ever had a project starting with a good idea, and you never get far with it. One day you return to it and you can't get in sync with what you had in mind. That sort of thing is what this game feels like.Atleast I can say the premise and idea is good, but I really can't figure out anything else good to say.All characters are flat because the game is infatuated with setpieces (I hope you like grey!) and trying to force emotions and exposition onto the player. I find an older man coughing that needs an inhaler, and I move on since I don't have one. Logic tells me there's one close by and as I move on the man says "I guess you want to help me but just can't yet". There's no understanding of immersive dialogue here. When I get him the inhaler he starts to spout exposition like everything in the game seems to want to. "Lemme guess, you wanna know more about the event right?" No I'm looking for medicine.The very flow of the way everything comes at you is so unnatural. It feels like someone wrote a story that won't work so it was half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥into a game. Heck there's enough hipsters in gaming that some would say it's well done.It's like someone makes a little game and tells you to try it and say you can explore on your own. Although the moment you go left where they'd prepared an event to the right, the guy rips the controller from your hands and says, "oh no no, you don't want that. Look over here is something cool"... In my exploring the game literally gave me a prompt "You weren't supposed to go this way, turn back." Gees.. let me just look around.From the very beginning the camera is a problem and game has tons of technical issues. Every gameplay aspect is so on rails, rinse and repeat.This game was looking interesting when announced way back, but it went through a lot of reworking and it's easy to see it's become a leather faced abomination. Everything game-like is lacking and drowning in the game's pretentiousness.I'd say i've already said too much about this game, when there's not much worth mentioning. I Am Alive is incredibly pretentious and poorly designed, executed and unfinished. The end.I don't enjoy slamming a game when it's gifted to me, but at the end of the day I gotta be honest.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												It shows that this title went through development hell, which is an incredible shame. At it's core, it's a fantastic survival game. It features chilling atmosphere worthy of a space next to The Road. The gameplay is fun. It falls short in a few areas and is by no means perfect (it would be nice if there was a better stealth mechanic to the game). When it comes to the story, it's entertaining, but short with a very unresolved and abrupt ending---It feels as though the game's development hell caused only the first half of it to be completed.The exploration levels would be fun if it wasn't for the incredibly aggrivating and pointless checkpoint save/retry system. You could spend 20 minutes exploring Haventon collecting loot only to die and have the game revert to the beginning of the level without retaining any of your found items.All in all, there is enough here to make up for the pitfalls and make it worth playing, especially if it's on sale. It's a shame this game didn't do well for the studio. I would gladly play a sequel that was given a proper development cycle.

content:

												The graphics are alright, nothing to write home about but not horrific.The mechanics are interesting, I like the intimidation part and having to think about your actions (somewhat), I played it on survivor mode and it was hard... up until the hotel. Once I got past the hotel I managed to down everything with one arrow, until I got to the pier and got a second arrow at which point I didn't need a gun and ended the game on a mountain of ammo, the pier mission was also incredibly short, if they thought having large battles with a bunch of enemies would provide difficulty or make it all seem longer then they were wrong.The items were all but useless, I could've started up my own community and fed them for years by the end of the game I had that much crap.Saving people was... alright I guess, but having to trek the entire city to go back to someone you saw at the start of the game just before finishing the game to give them a tomato is taking the♥♥♥♥♥♥I hate the way they separate segments of a mission, and that I never got to see what those horrific and scary looking mutant-ish shadows were in the dust clouds.And the ending, my god the ending. While I won't join everyone in saying it's the worst ending in history, as we know that's not true. It did seem very rushed and I expected it in all honesty and it leaves a ton of loose ends.Having said this, I believe it works very well as a cliffhanger, people complain that it gives you no closure and leaves you confused but that's what it's supposed to do and it does it well, I think that it leaves plenty of opportunity for another game.To summarize, I do believe it is a good game and I respect what they were trying to do, and I enjoyed the mechanics (Except the ♥♥♥♥ing dust, nothing but a godamn hassle) I would suggest people pick it up and play on survivor for the experience of a tough game with nice platforming and a plot line tha

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 24, 2016
												Another game port from console to PC from Ubisoft, another failure they refuse to fix.For the amount of time this game has been out, its rather disappointing to see such a good looking game go down the drain. Input lag, unstable areas that even an R9 390 cant handle and broken parts that make the game just unplayable isn't a good sign. I never played this on console, however after plugging in a controller, I still found the game to stutter and most of the time not even register many button presses. This caused me to fail some missions, not due to difficulty, but due to my button presses not being registered by the game. After revealing the controller to not be the fix, I moved back to mouse and keyboard. Certain areas will almost appear as though the game has switched your DPI down automatically as dragging the mouse around stops working momentarily. This issue I found most annoying.My opinion would be to buy this game only if you're a Ubisoft fan, and don't intend on playing it or can overlook these issues, but to everyone else, the game is too broken to enjoy. I was lucky enough to pick up this game at 80% off, but still feel ripped off. If you do buy/have bought it, I'd recommend requesting a refund or else it'll end up being another addition to your steam library that will get uninstalled and never installed again.

number of helpful: 13 of 26 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 19, 2014
												I felt like the objectives and areas were far too forced and like I didn't have the options that were portrayed in the trailers. Finding and using bullets only one at a time was contrived and made it obvious (I clearly currently have this single bullet so that I can break that single lock to go to the next space) and obligatory. The multi-level movement was difficult, contrived, and overall didn't feel right. As cool as it was to be rewarded for hanging off a building by a sewer pipe by being given access to the next area, dying six times because you didn't see and aim for the sewer pipe many seconds before the roof you're balanced on collapses for no reason is excessive. Honestly, I felt like the game's movement could have been replaced by a point and click system where the screen is presented to you all at once, then your monkey-man character climbs six stories up an elevator shaft with a child on his back because you clicked a single button. I wanted to absolutely love the game and was overall not just disapointed that it wasn't great, but crushed that it was actually bad.

number of helpful: 18 of 37 people (49%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 24, 2014
												"Hidden gem" my bum bum.I stopped enjoying this one 30 minutes into the game, maybe even before that point.In general this is a usual Ubisoft game - rushed, glitchy, feels unfinished, at times simply annoying.Obnoxious camera with broken sensitivity if you're using mouse and keyboard - I had to switch to a controller 'cos I simply couldn't handle it. There are two different sensitivities for when you're running in 3rd person and when you're simply walking. Only the second one can be changed, which results in the camera being utterly glitchy when you're running with high sensitivity options.Weird and annoying retry system that makes close to none sense when the game restarts you a second before you pick up another retry. Now, if you somehow still want to play this game, I'd suggest starting on easy. I went with survival and switched around 2h to easy simply cos of the game being made so poorly.Combat is.... it's something that made me rage internally at least a dozen times, even after switching to easy. It's this... I don't even... It's a mess. It tries to be realistic but fails so many times due to it feeling rushed and glitchy (as the whole game). At times you will kill 1 out of 3 guys and be left pointing your empty gun at 2 of them. Now if you don't have anything else and are forced to melee, you can already restart since if you want to kill one of the remaining two bad guys you will have to go into this QTE which resolves around you MASHING one button but since it takes around 3-5 secs to finish that, the last enemy will just rush to you and interrupt that leaving you basically dead. The only thing that you could do in this situation is spam "back off" till one of them is at the end of the map so he won't be able to interrupt you. Or somehow try to be stealthy (there's no stealth system btw) and pray to the RNG gods as well as the bugs gods. It's possible to do but in no way fun. Add to that some delay when pulling gun at enemies - sometimes they'll still feel brave even though you can shoot them easily. The delay is usually around 2 secs and can result in your death most of the time. Oh, and yes.. At some point the game introduces the "kill the though guy, rest will surrender" mechanic which worked... you've guessed it.. once. You will never do this because your priority will be to kill the guys with guns first and pick those up as fast as you can so that you don't have to waste more ammo on other enemies that will pick up said guns and be the threat again.To finish the combat bit I will add that AI is just.. marvelous. In this one instance I SHOT 2 people but one of the enemies felt somewhat brave and went with the line close to "Can you even shoot? I bet you won't have the balls to.". Yeah...The game doesn't feel fun in general. It's like a chore... I'd understand the game being difficult, but the game being difficult 'cos it's an unfinished piece of Ubicrap? Sorry, no. Story is.... uninteresting at best with the ending being a huge middle finger to your face and a cliffhanger saying "want to actually finish the game? Buy the next one." (which afaik will never get made). Not to mention that what you're doing has hardly any meaning for the main protag. The game is a pack of side quests resolved around other people and their problems. You're always helping someone, everyone else has 2 left hands and you're this knight on a white horse. Meh.Not a single interesting/likeable character. Protag is this shell of a character, stating the obvious for the most of the time and following commands of other people. The kid with the head that's 50% of her body in the first cutscene is your typical sick child needing rescue with 0 personality, same as her guardian and mother. Not to mention people you can rescue/help. I really wanted to shoot that starving woman who said she wouldn't touch the meat but wanted 2 cans of vegies out of me. For the record, there were 2 types of meat in the game - human meat and rat meat. Afaik she didn't state which one is a no-no for her so... yeah..."So, Extinox, have you enjoyed anything in this game?"Actually yes. Not greatly but I still enjoyed it, I guess. Climbing was somewhat fun. Of course not at all times 'cos of well.. glitches but it was mediocre and thus better than the other parts of the game.EDIT: Oh, I forgot to add how it somehow uses 90% of my CPU most of the time and how sound is broken if you're running 5.1. The middle speaker will simply produce no sound. I will never forget the moment when there was a storm going on around me but when I set my camera to a specific angle, I wouldn't hear anything.

number of helpful: 16 of 33 people (48%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 20, 2014
												I am SO VERY HAPPY that I purchased this game as a Halloween special, I think I paid $3.00 for it. I have a special liking for post-apocalyptic games, but if I had paid full price for this I would have been very upset. The game starts off promising, with a bleak color scheme and appropriate moody music as you're placed in the shoes of a character who's arrived at his home town, and is trying to find a way to his dwelling. You have a gun but no bullets. OK, fine. Mad Max didn't have bullets for his gun half the time, but it was still an unforgettable experience of a movie. You come to a bridge which has been blown to pieces, and the tutorial system helpfully prompts you to jump the gap here, climb the post there. OK, fine. Normally I have little patience for jumping puzzles, but Half Life had its share, and that was one of the best games I ever played.And this is where the game betrays its console roots. And no, I'm not a PC purist. I own a PS2, and PS3, and a Wii. I grew up playing Nintendo. There are some wonderful console games out there. This is not one of them. Here is why: While climbling, you have a stamina meter. OK, fine. Realistic. No one can hang by their fingers indefinately. You have to climb smart, or you'll run out of energy and fall. But, the game doesn't merely expect you to use common sense. It presents a jumping/climbing puzzle that demands perfection. You have JUST ENOUGH energy to make it where you need to get to. If you waste ANY time, even so much as a tenth of a second, you're going to fail. And fail. And fail some more. After ten tries I was able to get close to my objective. After ten more tries I was able to begin a final reach to the sanctuary of a ledge. And that's as close as I got. After the seventh time of running out of energy and falling to my death within that final reach, I gave up. Any game that throws a puzzle like this at you, a puzzle where literally one tenth of a wasted second counts, at the very beginning of the game... Well, to quote Eric Cartman, "Screw you guys, I'm going home." Some players would view this as a challenge. More power to them. I view it as frustrating and as lazy game design.To be fair, I'm not doing this game justice by reviewing it after only an hour of gameplay. But I say if the first bite of a sandwich contains excrement, you have no one else to blame if you take a second bite. Or, God forbid, finishing the entire thing just because you paid good money for it. And scanning other reviews has indicated that this opening puzzle of frustration is only the tip of the iceberg.  The funny thing is, I've spent far more time writing this review than such a game deserves. But if I save even one gamer from throwing away $15.00 on this, then my work is done here.

content:
Posted: November 6, 2014
												After about an hour of playing this game, here is my view of it:[5/10] Graphics-wise, it's extremely white/bright and has that horrible grain effect that doesnt let you fully enjoy the beauty of the map that isn't actually there.[5/10] Sound-wise, The audio was all over the place. I suppose the support for 5.1/7.1 surround sound was horribly done in the game, because any people that talked were always somewhere else than from where the sound was coming from.[3/10] Controls-wise, the controls are a little irritating, and for me, getting the camera to move at all was a challenge. I would be dragging my mouse across my entire desk just for the game to recognise that I wish to turn (no, it isnt the sensitivity, something is stopping the camera from moving). This may just be me, but it made it un-playable and ruined the game within the first 5 minutes.[1/10] Combat-wise, absolutely lazy. Ammo is extremely scarce, from what i've seen (and from other reviews), you constantly have only one bullet at your disposal. The only way to melee people is to get up-close and personal to them. while everyone is attempting stabbing you in the sides, you gotta walk up and press 'E' to attack. (I may be missing another form of combat/control, but trying over and over I couldn't find anything, correct me if I'm wrong).[6/10] Story-wise, somewhat enjoyable. Even though the start is a bit cheesy, the story seems to have more pontential than anything else in the game. While only an hour in, however, I can't say much about it.[3/10] Options-wise, there are almost no customization settings what-so-ever. In the video settings, you can change the brightness, the resolution, the aspect ratio, anti-aliasing, the graphic quality itself (low, medium, or high), FXAA, or VSync. This menu leaves you no room to really adjust the graphics for that 'high quality' look. The audio settings is just the volumes of main, music, voice, and sound effects. This doesn't bother me as much, but I was hoping for some options for surround-sound, coming from a semi-stealth game.Overall I would say this game is about a 4/10 from my view of it within an hour of game-time. I may be missing more good things or bad things about the game, but so far this game wasn't worth it.

content:
Posted: November 6, 2014
												Bought this game when it was on sale for Halloween. For three dollars, yeah it'd be worth it. For full price? No.In short, it's very simplistic and feels very lazy. The characters are laughably simplistic with very little background ever established... which would really help given the main character seems to have the skillset of an Assassin from the Assassin's Creed franchise. I really would like to know how he's able to scale bridges and parkour on the level he does.For a game about survival in a post-apocalyptic world there's very little actual survival and more on-rails walking engagement to engagement. You can't scavenge from the rubble, can't check inside containers or trash cans. This by itself hurts immersion.What totally kills the immersion is the fact that even the fights are puzzles. You have to kill certain enemies in certain ways and in a certain order or you're dead before you know it. Stranger still is the ability to carry just one bullet for your magazine-fed handgun. There's no simple melee, no way to counter someone running up on you and no way to grapple someone less than a foot away from you with a firearm.Even the animations are lazy. There's a scene wherein the main character is carrying a child on his back and ends up having to use his machete to break a chain. Our hero then sheaths this machete into the child's character model.In conclusion? Boring, frustrating and not worth it. For a much better urban survival experience I'd reccomend the Fallout franchise.

content:
Posted: December 9, 2014
												I Am Alive is easily one of my favorite games, it has a decent plot and fairly well acted voice-overs. The gameplay is a mix of Resident Evil style scavenging and Prince of Persia-esque climbing sections.   Your characters stamina bar plays a huge part in how you play this game. Most every action causes it to drain. Running, climbing, and struggling to break locks. When you enter the areas the NPC's refer to as "the fog", which is dust and ash in the air caused by storms your stamina constantly drains. Do you risk a few more moments searching dusty streets for vital resources, or climb back up to saftey and let it recharge? You will find yourself constantly watching it well into the later ares of this game.  You will come across other survivors and you must decide what to do. Some may be hostlie, some may need help, the intimatation combat is very well done in this game. You are actually able to hold hostiles at gunpoint even when you may not have any ammo. Don't wait too long to act or they may realize your gun is empty and attack.   I am currently on my second playthrough of this one and still get the feelings I got when playing it the first time.  Fear, panic, sadness... all are present here throughout the entire game. You never feel overly powerful even after getting some of the better gadgets and weapons. The downside to this game is the rather low resolution textures. However seeing that this is and always has been a $15 dollar title, It can be forgiven as the game is thouroughly entertaining.

content:
Posted: April 25, 2016
												DO NOT BUYThis is the worst survival game I have ever played. Where do I even start...Bad controls. For example, you run using a left mouse button! The left mouse button! Yes, you can change key bindings but the same button is used for shooting, so you either have both running and shooting on LMB or none of them.And this is even better: You can jump and climb only on specific spots where the developer allowed you to. Forget basic logic - you can climb this truck but not the same truck over there. You can grab this ledge but not that one. This turns the game into a guessing game. Guess where's the path the level designed made for you, because you can't go anywhere else!The savepoint system. There is only one hard savepoint at the beginning of each chapter. So if you leave the game too soon or the game crashes (happened multiple times to me), be prepared to replay last 20-30 minutes.There are also more soft checkpoints that you can use to spawn after death but the devs had another great idea - let's severely limit the number of respawns and if you spend them all, replay the whole chapter! Isn't it a great idea in a trial&error game where you can hardly predict or plan anything during your first playthrough? Splendid! Thankfully, the easy mode has unlimited respawns.The savepoint system has one other major catch. It also your saves your stamina capacity, health and ammo. And this brings the last "tiny" problem with...The stamina system. This is the thing that made me quit the game for good. I'm fine with a stamina bar that you need to recharge by resting a bit. But here, if you spend all stamina points (which is often unavoidable in this game) you maximum stamina capacity starts to decrease. And the capacity doesn't recover by itself, you need to use very rare consumables to get the full stamina back.So it's pretty easy to end up on a savepoint with only 20 % stamina bar, no consumables, and a long climbing sequence or a dust storm ahead. At this point your're done because it's impossible to continue, you die or fall almost immediately. Restarting the checkpoint doesn't help because it doesn't restore the stamina bar. And in my case the checkpoint was also a chapter savepoint so restarting the last chapter didn't help either. My only choices were either to restart the previous chapter and replay everything again (risking the same problem in the end), or to delete this piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥from my computer.I chose the latter.

content:
Posted: November 10, 2014
												I Am Alive might be one of the most ambitious and under-rated XBLA games of all time. The niceties that are usually reserved for AAA gaming experiences are all present here. The soundtrack is stunning, the gameplay is innovative, and the atmosphere is remarkable. That said, there are some problems with this game that do need to be addressed. For one, there's a grainy filter that runs over the screen for the entire game. This isn't a glitch, but a purposeful design choice by the developers, presumably to make the game feel more gritty (or something). I don't quite understand the need for it, and it makes the game look pretty ugly.There's also a stamina bar that slowly drains as you exert energy in the game, either by climbing buildings or traversing through the thick fog in the streets. When the bar gets about halfway down, the un-settling sound of shrieiking violins will fill your ears, indicating that your character doesn't have much longer to survive. This cranks the tension up to 11 during moments that might otherwise be a monotonous trudge, but by the 9th or 10th time it happens, you'll be looking for any excuse to avoid making your stamina drop. By the 50th time, you'll be taking off your headphones, setting them on your desk, and shaking your head in dissapointment. Sure, it's scary, and the sound sends chills up my spine, but there's no relief from it. That dreadful buzz will accompany nearly every moment of this game. It begins to feel like a cheap way to add horror into a game that really isn't that horrifying.Other than that, I Am Alive is captivating. The "intimidation" style combat feels excellent and believeable. Enemies will cower under your gun while you're pointing at them, but if you don't shoot for an extended period, they'll start to think you're bluffing, and they'll rush you. If you shoot while you're out of bullets, enemies will take note of it, and seize the oppurtunity to slice you with their machetes. It's a decently in-depth system for a downloadable title, and it makes you seriously consider each encounter carefully.Overall, I Am Alive is an impressive game. The story is simple, but well-told, and the character dialogue sounds natural. Shout-out to the voice actors as well, who do some amazing voiceovers for these characters. Their contribution to the game makes the world even more believable, and one that you'll want to get lost in.

content:
Posted: January 16, 2015
												+Atmosphere: Grey, dusty, bleak and dark. Just like a post-apocalypse should be.-Movement/Exploration: Most of the game time is spent trying to navigate, run, and climb your way from point A to point B. Frustrating for many gamers, but logical and realistic enough.-Equipment: Not much diversity, but then again, you ARE in a city that's been a wasteland for many months.+Story: The main character is an office worker, not an ex-navyarmy overpowering rambo. He wants to meet his family, not save the world. The enemies are everyone that doesn't need anything from youNo Zombies.The teaser at the ending left me itching for the sequel; though I must admit I expected a more fulfilling ending.++Stamina: Almost every action requires stamina, so excessive movement is a no-no. If you run out of stamina during a physically demanding task, you start using your health as stamina, which isn't far from what happens in real life.+++Combat: One enemy is doable. Two are iffy. Three require tactics. Any more without a bullet would be suicide without climbable ledges to run to.Fighting has the most realistic mechanic I've seen in a survival game. Feints and bluffs are the only means with which you may survive against overwhelming numbers (>2=overwhelming).Overall: The best cross between a survival simulation and a survival game I've ever tried.

content:
Posted: December 8, 2016
												Doggone this game pisses me off, primarily because the save system is so erratic and unpredictable.  I ended up doing the same things over and over again, simply because I don't have countless hours to wander around until I can finallly find a save point.  Even then a found save point is no guarantee that, if you log off entirely, that it won't throw you back to some vague save point from the past.  Very very frustrating with no sense whatsoever.  That coupled with the mouse usage in a fight or when lifting a door - you have to tap the LMB furiously to accomplish your task and believe me you can't do it with just your index finger resting on the LMB.  NOOOOO!!!  I have to hit "E", grab the mouse with my Left hand, then using my Right index finger, pound the LMB into submission.  And half the time that doesn't work either.  Games should be FUN, not endless repetitive work, so I'm giving this game a resounding thumbs down.  It's not a pretty game, the graphics and landscape interaction are minimal, and most of the time everything is shrowded in fog.  Pointless, simply pointless.        If you insist on playing this game here's a suggestion.  Play it on EASY.  The reason to do so is simple.  On any other level the only way you get to continue after you die, and you WILL die many many times, is if you accumulate "Replays" by saving somebody.  This is the ONLY benefit of saving somebody!  On EASY you get INFINITE REPLAYS.  That is the ONLY change in the game, so why not?  You control the game; the game doesn't control you!  Otherwise the game consists of saving the same characters OVER AND OVER AGAIN to accumulate replays to move on.  FRUSTRATING IN THE EXTREME.  If your ego or pride won't let you play on EASY, even tho it makes no difference any other way, then you get exactly what you deserve.

content:
Posted: December 22, 2014
												This game is highly underrated and has been given a questionable rating.This is possibly the top game in terms of a post-apocalyptic setting and gives players a pure believable survival experience. It's atmospheric setting in a darker world that we all know, and a plot to keep us enticed until the end shows us a gripping; captivating; depressing; miserable; and almost always utterly brilliant game. The crafty and clever use of a dust-filled city may make up for the graphics that have been questioned but I am quite comfortable with how they are regardless.An interesting feature, which I would love to see more in games, is their use of the gun. We can stick people up. Literally, if you want something in this world you can point your gun in their face and watch as they cower. You can do the right thing and help people with supplies that are scarce, or rob them.Do not underestimate the scarcity of supplies because as I said before, it IS the most believable survival experience.I actually felt like I robbed them for getting this on sale :/Epic game and I am still looking for another game like it. 9/10

content:
Posted: November 9, 2015
												All around good game. Graphics aren't spectcular, but its not really a problem. Has the atmosphere of the Last of Us, but thats about it. Gameplay is best described as a puzzler. You have to think before you act otherwise youll more than likely die. I don't really like that one mistake makes it 99.9% you'll die, but I guess that's a bit more realistic. Some moments seemed really challenging, and were almost too difficult at times, at least in terms of combat. Climbing aspect was fun and a good way to challenge your mind. However in terms of control, it could be unresponsive. trying to slide down a pole could cause you to move left or right several times instead, (which if you play you'll understand why it can be frustrating) and aiming, shooting, attacking could also freakout at times, but mostly aiming because of accidental switching between targets. Armored enemies were kind of OP because there were only two weak points, and because of tedious aiming capability made it hard to be accurate. Stealth was hardly even an optin because as soon any of the characters are in visual range they react, and most are placed in a way that makes it impossible. Player interaction with NPC's was limited to combat, or helping them out. the decision making was kimited to "Do I have the item they need or not, and am I willing to spend the time to get it?" And finally the ending seemed abrupt, and was a cliffhanger that made no sense. However the characters were enjoyable. I'd say maybe 6 or 7/10

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 20, 2015
												The game I am Alive was made by Darkworks from 2005-2008 and switch midway through to Ubisoft Shanghai And was released in 2011 on Xbox live arcade,PSN,and Microsoft Windows.For a game that was in development for over 5 years this game should be close to flawless but instead the game is incredibly bland and feels like it was made in 2 days by one guy.this is a post apocalyptic game after some thing caused the world to go to hell,Whatever caused this series of events to happen isn't explained at all.You play as Adam Collins a man trying to find his family after he went on a buisness trip across the country before everything went down.At the start of the game you watch a tape recording of him talking to who ever can find it and tells them what he has with him,He has a Bag,rope and a gun which he hasn’t used yet,but fires like a pro during gameplay.Without spoiling to much the the story is really just about him finding his family.The gameplay in this game is god awful.The camera switches from 3rd to 1st person,the enimeis dont die by a machete to the face or a bullet to the heart ,the gun is useless,the controls are afwul,the A.I is rediculous,the story is bland and boring, the stamina is so bad if you run for 2 seconds you become very tired or if your climbing you just fall off and die.This isnt a game its a joke.The only real “good” thing about this game is the world is very well done and the graphics are good.The price i would reccomend buying this for is if and only if this game becomes free to play.Overall I would have to give this game a 17/100.Thats being generous.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 22, 2014
												The only good thing about this game is the cinematics and hold ups besides that it's got nothing going for it; It has none of that scavenging/survival feel to it because nothing is off of the plot line besides one or two survivors who are too lazy to move.The poly textures on the non interactive props is embarassing; skeletons made of 1 poly which don't even look like skeletons EVEN when my graphics quality is at high/ultra.The unexpected lag spikes; I fiddled about with the settinsg for over 15 minutes and I still got lag spikes (even when I went low-quality, no shadows, no light flare, no pixels and no motion blur)The stamina bar/food and drink system doesn't make the game any better, if anything it makes it worse; the guy looks like he goes to the gym but he has the stamina of a fat man walking to the shop AND to top that when you go critical it means "furiously" clicking and when you stop your stamina has permanently depleted by a fraction unless you eat a pack of crisps or a candy bar.... logicThe stand ups; GREAT when you do it, rubbish when they do it to you; because you're always in 3rd person mode until you draw a weapon you see just how clunky the animations are (e.g. walks past small Asian lady with a gun, in 0.01 of a second he snaps 90 degrees to the left and faces her with his hands up until he gets "out of her sight" aka over 20 foot away from her)Looting; when looting dead enemies which had infinite ammo for some reason you're lucky to get 1 bullet 1 out of every 5 kills. When going into abandoned buildings all you find is 2 food packs, 1 or 2 bullets and a note which IS related to the plot (there are absolutely NO subplots or side plots)Sensitivity; the sensitivity was through the roof on this game for the mouse, I had my mouse set at its lowest setting and I had the in-game setting at its lowest but still moving my mouse an inch was a 360 BUT that can only be said for the x-axis, the y-axis on the other hand took my mouses HIGHEST setting to look fully up/down.Intimidating; you had well over 10 encounters with "bandits" but yet Ubisoft thought 3-4 voice commands will suffice.Attacks; when encounters with bandits happen you're held at gun point, dude with the gun walks up to you and starts pushing you backwards, QUICK TIME EVENT, you slash the dudes throat but there is no gore...disappointed. And although you have a combat knife you never think to use it in combat cos only real men fight with fists and empty guns.General observation; the character has been designed with a role coil going round his chest but he never thinks to use it.Jumping distances; constantly changing and always making no sense, there were more than 5 occasions when I thought I could make that jump, NOPE you need to climb this 100 foot tower, then go over the 30 foot connector and then along a 50 foot wire and back down a 100 foot tower to progress...... 10 metres.I'm not saying this is a bad game.... I'm just not saying it's a good game... because of it's 1 or 2 (million) faults

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 2, 2015
												This game is nearly everything I wanted from a Post-apocalyptic game! It was still a whole lot different than I imagined, but in a good way. Unfortunately you can definitely tell that this game wanted to be more than it is, as it is missing some stuff which would have made this game even better; but I'll get back to that. It's a good game that shows us that Zombies aren't the threat in a post-apocalyptic world (not that there are zombies in this game) but that people are threat. In this game you might hear someone crying for help, but it could just be a trap set in place so they can rob you of well you're life. So you have to beware of who you help and don't help. Also since items are very scarce, you have to ask yourself if you want to help this person giving him/her your last health pack or do you keep it for yourself. These are great questions but to my dismay the choices you make don't really impact the game. If you for example help someone, they usually just say thank you and you get an extra retry.  In fact the only reason to help someone in this game would be to get the achievement for helping all victims in the game. If however helping someone would impact the story line; for example the person you saved ends up helping you later in the game or perhaps you helped the wrong person, and that person later then screws you over in the story. Well I think you can imagine that would have made the choices in the game so much more interesting. Now theyre just NPCS that stare at you after you help them...well umm great. So yeah theres a lot of potential for this game to be the best post-apocalyptic game ever but it unfortunately just misses the mark. I also feel like the fighting options are quite limited but maybe im just bad at the game. Either way I still found it a really enjoyabel game to play, and I do think I will replay the game again at some point just to save all the victims in the game. However the missed potential in this game stares at me with every NPC you save (they literally just stare at you). It's just such a shame no one has tried to improve on this concept because that would make the best post-apocalyptic game ever!!!In conclusion, you should get this game! but feel free to wait for a steam sale. As long as you play 6 euros or less, it is worth it as you will definitely get 6 hours of gameplay; even from a rushed playthrough!
