content:
Posted: September 20, 2012
												The game starts off very linear and looks to be a little generic, however the first combat scene gets interesting and you see a fighting mechanistic unlike any other game (persuasion/trickery). As you wonder the streets you look for your lost family after a terrible global accident. You have spent the last few years traveling all the way from the East Coast of the U.S to the West Coast to find your “possibly alive” family. When you reach your home you find it empty and no family insight, however see a little girl looking for her mother that seems to look like your daughter. Deciding you have nothing to lose (and maybe a little desperate) you follow her. You soon find out that her mother has been taken by bandit and that the little girl is very ill. Your only “friend” is Henry, the man that is looking after them... It's up to you to save the girl and the mother and hopefully find your family.-=Scoring=-Gameplay 9/10Story: 9/10Creativity: 9/10Graphics 7/10

content:
Posted: August 16, 2014
												I really dig this game for a lot of reasons, but foremost is the combat. Here's how the last encounter I had went when I finally nailed it after running low on the hard-to-come-by retries.I walk into an area and am surrounded, 2 guys behind me and 3 in front. I quickly note that 2 of the guys are armored (one being behind me), the second man behind me has a gun, and the other 2 simply have knives. I also notice a bonfire in the corner. Then I make my plan and execute.First I back up without revealing that I'm armed or willing to fight. However, the guy who approaches me is the armored guy who was behind me. Since he's armored, I can't kill him with a quick knife. So I continue backing up for a couple seconds until the only guy behind me is the one with a gun, and then I strike.I attack the gunman with my surprise strike, killing off the gunner and leaving the 4 others in front of me without a way to get between me to the dead man's gun. I then have to immediately toggle to precision aim, and aim quickly to shoot the armored man who was harassing me before he slashes me and while the other 3 enemies approach.Once I shoot the first armored man pointblank, I can quickly cycle between the 2 unarmored men and convince them to start backing up, realizing that I have a gun with ammo. The 2nd armored man continues approaching with his bulletproof vest, so I have to quickly switch to precision aiming and shoot him in the head.At this point there are 2 men with knives left. I tell them both to keep backing up, separating them and forcing one to back up to the fire. I then kick the poor man into the fire to die, and quickly turn as the final man starts sprinting at me when he realizes I'm still looking to kill. I choose to save the 1 round of ammunition that I have left, and catch him in a one-on-one knife battle, knowing that I can finally win it without his buddies around to save him.I walk away from 5 dead bodies with only 1 round of ammunition left, wondering how I can make it out of an even larger battle next time.I highly recommend this game. It has its flaws, but it's easy to look past them with combat as thrilling and intense as this.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 6, 2014
												Let me begin by saying when first seeing the original announcement trailer for I Am Alive, I was extremely excited. The concept was very interesting and while it seemed to be an action game there were large psycological aspects to the play style that could make for a dynamic and unique game. After a long while I had forgotten about the game and assumed it to be vaporware only to suddenly find it alive on steam, no pun intended. I immediately seized it and excitedly dove right in. Disappointment set in quickly and I now wish it had stayed lost, maintaining my fantasy of what it might have been.  I Am Alive is a post-apocalyptic survival game. Food, resources, and ammunition are scarce and people have devolved into animalistic cliques who follow a kill or be killed morality. You come in one year in the aftermath of a great earthquake which has destroyed your home town of Haverton. Looking for your wife and daughter you meet with Mei, a young girl who you connect with and decide to protect. My first qualm with this game comes with its flimsy plot line. The game immediately begins with a clear set goal in mind and then immediately falls off track and begins following a long series of tangents to a quite unfinished ending. Along this way you meet various crooks and characters of whom you only learn of three names leaving the rest as expendables with whom you make no connections. Rewards for helping these people are generally bland and unsatisfying despite considerable effort and padding in order to help them. Worse, while many could easily have something interesting to say or do, they rather instead go straight to a generic need item, recieve item, thank you formula. Enemies are just as bad, consisting of roughly 4 or five different character models and all resulting in the same action to solve the problem, kill the one with the gun first, kill the rest second. The game gives the appearance of giving options without presenting the other choices. There isn't really a diplomatic way to deal with enemies (ordering to surrender, bribing them to leave, tying them up), and if you're lucky after killing half of them, one may offer to let you knock him unconcious. My initial interest in this game came from the idea of having alot of ways to handle enemies and being given the choice between the easy way, murder, and the hard way diplomacy and mercy. Items are scarce in the game, but not very scarce apparently. There are some 20 different items in the game all performing some combination of the same three functions, restoring stamina, restoring strength, and restoring health. While a particular item may be scarce there seems to be no end the items to fill any one of these purposes. If you only have a single soda can you most likely have come across 6 or 7 water bottles, for example. Each of these items at some point can be used to help a victim solve a problem but it is frustrating when you do not have an item on your one chance meeting with a particular victim. In many cases its even more frustrating when an item serves no other real purpose but to help this victim, despite the item being readily available (cigarettes and wine). Along with this many of the victims seem to need this item only for the purpose of giving an item something to do (again cigarettes and wine). It again adds to the unfinished feeling the game gives.The environment in the game is . . . well, gray. Exteremly gray in fact. I understand the idea of soot and ash covering the town making it this way but there is a serious lack of any color in this game indoors or out. I mean orange fire, yellow dust, red brick,  and blue water bottles should not be outside the realm of possibility. I originally thought that my character was severly injured and this was some sort of indicator of his deteriorated state, similar to other survival games, however that is the entire game. While the intent was clearly to give the player the feeling of depression washing over the city, it goes from sad to boring quickly. Action scenes feel drab and uninteresting when not only repetetive  but also made up of a single constant color throughout the short five hour playthrough. Did I mention short? Cause five hours was the entire game, padding and all. The core gameplay of I Am Alive could be broken down to one hour of actual play time and 4 hours of walking through dust cloud and climbing. While climbing mechanics in certain games such as Uncharted or Tomb Raider have been made exciting by quick time events, and active gameplay through the process, I Am Alive has made the sequence tedious. Adding the stamina bar would be an interesting twist on the game if it did not add to the padding between actual gameplay. Overall probably the biggest let down in game history, and that includes Duke Nukem. I hope the developers can sleep alright at night.

content:
Posted: July 24, 2016
												I've had enough. This game brought me the edge of my patience. Although I like the post-apocalyptic genre, this game sucks at "survival" concept. If I had wanted to play a platform game, I wouldn't have played this. I agree that the game has new things like limited ammo, strategical choice of killing enemies, stamina etc. But it shouldn't have been based on just climbing and ♥♥♥♥♥♥ stamina. Soundtrack and ambience music are cool; however that tension track whenever stamina decreases made me sick. Let's continue with the camera angles and character movements which were unsatifactory. It was hard to focus on enemy sight and game controls generally reacted late. Checkpoints saves were terrible. Although having retries when helping victims seems a good idea, losing all of them causes you to start over the chapter. The game setting was very good but those blurry graphics do not appeal to me. The story was cliche but I wasn't on that point actually. Sorry "I Am Alive", I really wanted to love you.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19, 2014
												This game is for serious post apocalyptic fans only.  I really wanted to love it but I just can't recommend it for the average gamer.ProsGreat level design, atmosphere, and texturesOkay story...good dialogueConsHorrendous controls (total console port)Camera control issuesFighting system is teh suckVery hardThere are some interesting ideas with the combat; the main one being you can use your gun to psych people out eventhough you may not have ammo.If you play this, I recommend doing it on Easy so you doing spend eternity replaying chapters.  It kind of being a sandbox (in that there are generally several ways to get to the same place) it does not allow for exploration very easily.The main mechanics are completely derived from the PS2 game Disaster Report, which in my mind created this genre of Tomb Raider platformer + management of health + disaster scenario.  Which is a good thing.  It means you really need to plan your actions especially while climbing. If you like climbing stuff and post apocalyptic environments, then it should be good. Otherwise, I would not bother.

content:
Posted: October 22, 2016
												I played this game, going in, expecting a meh game, the artsyle was what really grabbed me, having finished it, it is actually a really fun game, fun interesting mechanics with stamina, an open story to play as you wish, and a game where how you deal with a situation is actually dependent on your survival. Its like the last of us and uncharted had a love child, the survival elements, environment and level design is very last of us but there is alot of climbing and puzzels like uncharted, every bullet matters, If you like either Uncharted/Tomb Raider or Last Of Us, this is a great game to pick up, while I was initally frustrated with the game crashing twice, near the start, I am glad, I pressed on, its not the best on Windows 10 due to the 2 aformentioned crashes, but I had no problems after that point

content:
Posted: July 23, 2016
												Sadly I really wanted to like this game but could not.Graphics: Outdated but decent enough. There is a lack of colour, very drab. I can understand this type of art direction but in order for it to be effective you need some occasional constrast... of which there is none. No bright red blood. No yellow hues from an explosion. Not even the flashback/video cut scenes have much to offer.If the desire was to depress the player then the project manager succeeded.Audio: The sound design is nothing to write home about nor write much here in the review. The music is barely noticable and not in the good subtle way. The voice acting is fine and the sfx are okay but just okay.Plot: Fairly straight forward, no real twists or anything that would raise an eyebrow.Gameplay: A port and somewhat poor. The controls work fine once you fine tune but I got bored fairly quickly. I played about 2 hours on my pc and another 4 on a friend's. It just didn't grab me sadly. I did like the idea that bullets are extremely rare but what I don't understand is why people don't create other projectile weapons. A bow & arrow is simple and easy to make as is a crossbow, sling, throwing knives made from sharpen metal scrap etc. etc. Just seems weird that everyone only has melee weapons.If it's super cheap and you want to play you can finish it in 6 hours but I found it rather disappointing given the original CGI trailer I saw back in 2006 for PS3 games... it could have been something really interesting. Oh well plently of other post-apoc games out there.

Each of these items at some point can be used to help a victim solve a problem but it is frustrating when you do not have an item on your one chance meeting with a particular victim. In many cases its even more frustrating when an item serves no other real purpose but to help this victim, despite the item being readily available (cigarettes and wine). Along with this many of the victims seem to need this item only for the purpose of giving an item something to do (again cigarettes and wine). It again adds to the unfinished feeling the game gives.The environment in the game is . . . well, gray. Exteremly gray in fact. I understand the idea of soot and ash covering the town making it this way but there is a serious lack of any color in this game indoors or out. I mean orange fire, yellow dust, red brick,  and blue water bottles should not be outside the realm of possibility. I originally thought that my character was severly injured and this was some sort of indicator of his deteriorated state, similar to other survival games, however that is the entire game. While the intent was clearly to give the player the feeling of depression washing over the city, it goes from sad to boring quickly. Action scenes feel drab and uninteresting when not only repetetive  but also made up of a single constant color throughout the short five hour playthrough. Did I mention short? Cause five hours was the entire game, padding and all. The core gameplay of I Am Alive could be broken down to one hour of actual play time and 4 hours of walking through dust cloud and climbing. While climbing mechanics in certain games such as Uncharted or Tomb Raider have been made exciting by quick time events, and active gameplay through the process, I Am Alive has made the sequence tedious. Adding the stamina bar would be an interesting twist on the game if it did not add to the padding between actual gameplay. Overall probably the biggest let down in game history, and that includes Duke Nukem. I hope the developers can sleep alright at night.

content:
Posted: January 19, 2014
												This game is for serious post apocalyptic fans only.  I really wanted to love it but I just can't recommend it for the average gamer.ProsGreat level design, atmosphere, and texturesOkay story...good dialogueConsHorrendous controls (total console port)Camera control issuesFighting system is teh suckVery hardThere are some interesting ideas with the combat; the main one being you can use your gun to psych people out eventhough you may not have ammo.If you play this, I recommend doing it on Easy so you doing spend eternity replaying chapters.  It kind of being a sandbox (in that there are generally several ways to get to the same place) it does not allow for exploration very easily.The main mechanics are completely derived from the PS2 game Disaster Report, which in my mind created this genre of Tomb Raider platformer + management of health + disaster scenario.  Which is a good thing.  It means you really need to plan your actions especially while climbing. If you like climbing stuff and post apocalyptic environments, then it should be good. Otherwise, I would not bother.

content:
Posted: July 24, 2016
												I've had enough. This game brought me the edge of my patience. Although I like the post-apocalyptic genre, this game sucks at "survival" concept. If I had wanted to play a platform game, I wouldn't have played this. I agree that the game has new things like limited ammo, strategical choice of killing enemies, stamina etc. But it shouldn't have been based on just climbing and ♥♥♥♥♥♥ stamina. Soundtrack and ambience music are cool; however that tension track whenever stamina decreases made me sick. Let's continue with the camera angles and character movements which were unsatifactory. It was hard to focus on enemy sight and game controls generally reacted late. Checkpoints saves were terrible. Although having retries when helping victims seems a good idea, losing all of them causes you to start over the chapter. The game setting was very good but those blurry graphics do not appeal to me. The story was cliche but I wasn't on that point actually. Sorry "I Am Alive", I really wanted to love you.

												I played this game, going in, expecting a meh game, the artsyle was what really grabbed me, having finished it, it is actually a really fun game, fun interesting mechanics with stamina, an open story to play as you wish, and a game where how you deal with a situation is actually dependent on your survival. number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 23, 2016
												Sadly I really wanted to like this game but could not.Graphics: Outdated but decent enough. There is a lack of colour, very drab. I can understand this type of art direction but in order for it to be effective you need some occasional constrast... of which there is none. No bright red blood. No yellow hues from an explosion. Not even the flashback/video cut scenes have much to offer.If the desire was to depress the player then the project manager succeeded.Audio: The sound design is nothing to write home about nor write much here in the review. The music is barely noticable and not in the good subtle way. The voice acting is fine and the sfx are okay but just okay.Plot: Fairly straight forward, no real twists or anything that would raise an eyebrow.Gameplay: A port and somewhat poor. The controls work fine once you fine tune but I got bored fairly quickly. I played about 2 hours on my pc and another 4 on a friend's. It just didn't grab me sadly. I did like the idea that bullets are extremely rare but what I don't understand is why people don't create other projectile weapons. A bow & arrow is simple and easy to make as is a crossbow, sling, throwing knives made from sharpen metal scrap etc. etc. Just seems weird that everyone only has melee weapons.If it's super cheap and you want to play you can finish it in 6 hours but I found it rather disappointing given the original CGI trailer I saw back in 2006 for PS3 games... it could have been something really interesting. Oh well plently of other post-apoc games out there.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 6, 2014
												Let me begin by saying when first seeing the original announcement trailer for I Am Alive, I was extremely excited. The concept was very interesting and while it seemed to be an action game there were large psycological aspects to the play style that could make for a dynamic and unique game. After a long while I had forgotten about the game and assumed it to be vaporware only to suddenly find it alive on steam, no pun intended. I immediately seized it and excitedly dove right in. Disappointment set in quickly and I now wish it had stayed lost, maintaining my fantasy of what it might have been.  I Am Alive is a post-apocalyptic survival game. Food, resources, and ammunition are scarce and people have devolved into animalistic cliques who follow a kill or be killed morality. You come in one year in the aftermath of a great earthquake which has destroyed your home town of Haverton. Looking for your wife and daughter you meet with Mei, a young girl who you connect with and decide to protect. My first qualm with this game comes with its flimsy plot line. The game immediately begins with a clear set goal in mind and then immediately falls off track and begins following a long series of tangents to a quite unfinished ending. Along this way you meet various crooks and characters of whom you only learn of three names leaving the rest as expendables with whom you make no connections. Rewards for helping these people are generally bland and unsatisfying despite considerable effort and padding in order to help them. Worse, while many could easily have something interesting to say or do, they rather instead go straight to a generic need item, recieve item, thank you formula. Enemies are just as bad, consisting of roughly 4 or five different character models and all resulting in the same action to solve the problem, kill the one with the gun first, kill the rest second. The game gives the appearance of giving options without presenting the other choices. There isn't really a diplomatic way to deal with enemies (ordering to surrender, bribing them to leave, tying them up), and if you're lucky after killing half of them, one may offer to let you knock him unconcious. My initial interest in this game came from the idea of having alot of ways to handle enemies and being given the choice between the easy way, murder, and the hard way diplomacy and mercy. Items are scarce in the game, but not very scarce apparently. There are some 20 different items in the game all performing some combination of the same three functions, restoring stamina, restoring strength, and restoring health. While a particular item may be scarce there seems to be no end the items to fill any one of these purposes. If you only have a single soda can you most likely have come across 6 or 7 water bottles, for example. Each of these items at some point can be used to help a victim solve a problem but it is frustrating when you do not have an item on your one chance meeting with a particular victim. In many cases its even more frustrating when an item serves no other real purpose but to help this victim, despite the item being readily available (cigarettes and wine). Along with this many of the victims seem to need this item only for the purpose of giving an item something to do (again cigarettes and wine). It again adds to the unfinished feeling the game gives.The environment in the game is . . . well, gray. Exteremly gray in fact. I understand the idea of soot and ash covering the town making it this way but there is a serious lack of any color in this game indoors or out. I mean orange fire, yellow dust, red brick,  and blue water bottles should not be outside the realm of possibility. I originally thought that my character was severly injured and this was some sort of indicator of his deteriorated state, similar to other survival games, however that is the entire game. While the intent was clearly to give the player the feeling of depression washing over the city, it goes from sad to boring quickly. Action scenes feel drab and uninteresting when not only repetetive  but also made up of a single constant color throughout the short five hour playthrough. Did I mention short? Cause five hours was the entire game, padding and all. The core gameplay of I Am Alive could be broken down to one hour of actual play time and 4 hours of walking through dust cloud and climbing. While climbing mechanics in certain games such as Uncharted or Tomb Raider have been made exciting by quick time events, and active gameplay through the process, I Am Alive has made the sequence tedious. Adding the stamina bar would be an interesting twist on the game if it did not add to the padding between actual gameplay. Overall probably the biggest let down in game history, and that includes Duke Nukem. I hope the developers can sleep alright at night.

												This is the first time I've had fun with a linear game like this. Even though you dont have several choices in your path and area to move ahead, the choices come during your interactions with other people. "Do I use my last first aid kit on these injured strangers?" "Do I need to use this last bullet to survive?" "Which one do I use it on?" etc. Although the graphics aren't incredibly detailed and flashy, it's still fitting for this game. The climbing and jumping is kinda fun, but nothing as free as something like Assassin's Creed. Look at the price for this game though. Totally worth getting if you like post apoc games.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 2, 2012
												Wow. As far as I'm concerned, this game is severely underrated. Get it.Yes, it does have bits and pieces I don't like - the entire world is grey-brown-depressing, but then again, this is about a global apocalyptic event that destroyed the world as we knew it. I found myself looking up to the (red) health bar from time to time for a contrast, however.But it is surprisingly well-done. The music is good, and while the circumstances of "The Event" are never detailed, the repercussions are. Society has vanished and mankind is showing just how little it takes for everything  to deteriorate further. There's a shortage of everything - you feel like kissing every bullet before firing it at someone. Luckily (but a little late in the game) you will also find a hunting bow, with its arrows being re-usable.The only thing I don't really like is the ending, but for the sake of this being a recommendation, I won't spoil it for anyone. It is by no means a bad ending, just leaves me wanting more.

content:
Posted: September 7, 2012
												"Love it or hate it" type of game. It completely depends on your tastes. For me, its magnificent piece of art, which tells an amazing story of survival in ruined civilisation. Hardcore linear gameplay, resources management(1 single bullet can mean giant difference between life and death), new and unique fighting system. You just surprisingly killed one bully and immideatly shot other range-armed one? Remaining 2, armed only with meelee weapons, will♥♥♥♥♥♥their pants and surrender, even if you have no ammo left. Very interesting and very hard climbing and stamina management system too.TL;DR if you like survivals, rare resources management, "moral warfare" combat and beautifull storytelling, you will like this game. If you hate being limited in all aspects and want action, dont purchase it. There is also an easy mode if you want unlimited lives(plenty enough of them in normal mode, though).

content:
Posted: September 13, 2012
												I just finished this.  $15 for a 6 hour true surivial horror/apocalyptic game is a great deal.  The game runs flawlessy maxed out on my laptop and controls great with a mouse and keyboard.  The combat is something different and unlike anything else and the fatigue climbing system isn't that bad either.  The graphics really bugged me at first but the thick dust (somtimes you can't see more than a few yards infront of you), and film grain grew on me, it gave it a very eerie feel.  With a little more polish and time this could have been a great new IP but it's still great.   I'd say it's a must buy if you're a fan of surivial horror or apocalyptic games, especially at this price...and I can see myself playing through it again soon on harder difficulties.8/10

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2012
												I Am Alive is such a peculiar game. It's one of those games that I play, and don't really enjoy, but want to keep playing. I mean, The game is very ambitious, and I'm having some amount of fun with it, but there's just some things about it that you can't help but think how this game may have benefited from some different design choices.I enjoy the challenge that the limited continues provide.  It makes you want to play the game more carefully. I feel like the game rewards you for exploring, as you find additional items, and sometimes survivors to help, which will give you an additional retry, but it also punishes you by making your stamina go down, making you almost not want to explore.It's little things like that where the game is sending you mixed messages where it starts to feel like a chore to play. Yet, then I end up raiding an area with a whole bunch of enemies, and I have to carefully pick & choose my next move, trying to make people surrender, or pushing them far enough back to kick them off a ledge, or getting close enough to stab them with my machette. all the while, I'm making sure I do them all in the right order and quick enough in order to avoid getting hit, and conserving my ammo, which is very precious.  Some might find this tedious and complicated, but I find it tense & exhilirating.After you get through an area, just fighting group after group of guys, the game just makes you feel like this awesome Mad Max kind of character, and it's those moments, and the story (which is somewhat basic but kind of intriguing) that keeps me coming back to it.The game is definitely not for everyone, and it has it's flaws... but for people who enjoys survival horror games, or just games with interesting systems and mechanics, I'd say to definitely check it out.

												Pretty bland game play. Don't know if im even going to bother finishing it. The combat is horrid I mean seriously horrid as in its more of a puzzle then a fight since you get insta killed unless you follow the particular kill order the game pounds into your brain during the tutorial. Combat is in no way skill based you can not kill a fellow human being unless its 1v1 because each kill involves an annoying qte that takes 5-6 secs and leaves you totally vulnerable. Also health items are insanely hard to find and with no health regen you are going to be seeing alot of gray blurry screens unless you are really careful. Also platforming which reminds me of a kind of cluncky AC game are ruined by the stamina meter which makes every climb an annoying timed puzzle. Finally the story isn't exactly thrilling with everything being a bland fetch quest :P.Overall this game has become a chore to play and I strongly recommend people to avoid it.

content:
Posted: February 19, 2014
												I played about half of this game before getting sidetracked by other games. I have not yet returned to the game, but plan to eventually.There are three difficulty levels: Easy, Normal, and Survivor. I started out playing on Easy, but it was an unsatisfying experience. Then I played on the Survivor level, which was quite challenging, but more interesting and fun since resources (bullets, food, medicine) were scarce and I had to think carefully about whether or not to use each and when. The two biggest challenges were conserving my stamina as I climbed around and battling other survivors when they appeared in groups.The game does have a few problems. Most significant is the checkpoint save system. You cannot save your progress in the game yourself. Instead, the game saves your progress once you pass certain predetermined points. It's difficult to tell when these points will occur (or even when they have occurred) and they don't always occur when you might expect. They're also too widely spaced. This has the effect of intensifying your desire to push forward, but it also means you'll spend a fair amount of time retracing your recent progress.The control of your character, particularly when climbing, is sometimes glitchy and too unforgiving. There were many instances when I attempted to change direction during a climb and failed to do so because the character doesn't react quickly enough to the controls. The stamina mechanic, which limits the time you can spend climbing, can make this problem frustrating.You do not have complete freedom to take actions like jumping, climbing, or crouching. You'll be able to climb a fence or jump up on a crate in one area but you won't be able to do so in other identical areas. This intensifies the feeling that your progress through the game is predetermined and "on rails".Despite these problems, the game is engrossing. The visuals, voice acting, and atmosphere do a good job of drawing you into the game's post-apocalyptic world. Overall, I'd say the game serves up adequate, but not stellar, entertainment value. I bought the game during Steam's winter sale for $5 and so far feel like I'm getting my money's worth, but I don't think the game is worth more than $10.tl;dr Play the game on hardest difficulty for the best experience. The game's advantages (engrossing atmosphere and novel gameplay mechanics) are held back by some faults (a checkpoint save system, control issues, and lack of freedom) that result in the game being a fair, but not fantastic, value. Worth it for $5 but not at more than $10.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												Pros: Clever "threaten with gun" mechanics that make confrontations tense. You can practically taste the bleak, hostile and claustrophobic post-apocalyptic world. Climbing mechanics that are closer to Prince of Persia than Assassin's Creed, and add further tension and intensity with a Stamina meter and the chance of a lethal drop every few steps. The survival aspect is well-done, with exploration being about equally likely to lead to more of the sparse number of much-needed inventory items, as to another potentially deadly confrontation. Largely captures the grey moral nature of the post-apocalyptic world, like the movie The Road; no one can trust one another, and someone pointing a gun at you and/or threatening you may not be looking to kill and/or rob you, they may just be scared. Challenging. Once you've slid down a slanted skyscraper, jumped the gap in a modern bridge or barely made your way through a collapsed building, you will never again feel completely comfortable in our otherwise seemingly strong, sturdy buildings.Cons: Unless you're playing on Easy, the Retry feature is pretty ridiculous: you have to complete a level without running out of them(in spite of the trial-and-error nature of much of the game), meaning without making very many mistakes(you can earn extra Retries), or you have to start it all over - and trust me, in this, you will make mistakes. Once you've completed a level, you can do it over, but if you go back to a level before your current one, it will delete your progress beyond that level(forget about replayability)! If these aspects were something hardcore gamers could activate to challenge themselves, that would be fine, but with it being the way the game is designed, it loses a lot of potential fans. Ending is unsatisfying. The last third of the game is prepostorous - it's as if it was developed by someone else, and they thought it was a regular shooter, rather than a "make every last bullet count" survival game.My recommendation: Give it a go if you love at least one of the following: Prince of Persia style climbing, a survival challenge, dark post-apocalyptic fiction and unconventional approaches to taking out enemies.

												Me not really being a fan of the Adventure genre and getting this fairly cheap on sale, I didn't expect much from this title but I was surprised by a few things in this game. For a game that contained no monsters, zombies, aliens, killer machines, etc... it was still pretty creepy. Graphics were artfully done. Level design was great, though does get cheesey at times with how they limit your movement. Sounds were phenominal and really absorbed you into the suspense. (with out revealing anything) The storyline had a dark and a good message. On the other hand, I got 8 and a half hours out of this title before completing it on normal and does not offer much replayability. A minus for me. The next problem I had is that it is still a little glitchy and spontaneously assimilating with a rock face (or building, etc...) really puts a dampener on game progression (it sucks). Controls were a little touchy but you kind of get used to it. All in all, I'd give this game a 75% (solid C).  I hope Ubisoft considers making a 2 to pick up where this one left off and corrects the this issues that this one had but an all around decent game. Rox recommends (buy on sale)!

Posted: November 26, 2014
												I Am Alive is a bleak, depressing game. This doesn't make it a bad game. In fact, I think the atmosphere is quite good. In terms of the game itself the story is quite simple. A catostrohpic event happened while you were out of town. It has taken you a year to get back to your town and you are now trying to find your wife and child. On your quest to do this, you become connected with another family and you complete missions for them.The game is brutally hard even when not on the hardest difficulty. You have scare resources and you have a stamina meter that prevents you from climbing or running forever. Also, saving the game only happens at random, spread-out times that are not controlled by the gamer. I imagine this is one of the main reason the game got beat up by critics.Overall, I loved it even though it was completely bleak.

content:
Posted: March 28, 2013
												Set in a dark and dusty post-apocalyptic world, I Am Alive is pretty damn gritty. When you first boot up the game you may think the developers are aiming for a monochrome art style to reflect the emptiness of the world and the protagonist. Nope - it's just really, really dusty. Everything (seriously, everything) in the game is black, white, brown, or somewhere in between, with occasional splashes of red (to create an industrial feel as well as the obvious reason). Follow the exploits of Professor Brian Cox as he tries to find his family, help fellow survivors, and explain the Pauli exclusion principle to increasingly ignorant and hostile thugs. At times, this is deep, rewarding, and engaging stuff.Unfortunately for the Professor, his resources are somewhat limited. Our Lancastrian hero's weaponry is limited to his machete and a pistol. However, the latter seems to be used more as a mechanic for conserving resources than as a weapon, as bullets can only be found from enemies who have...guns! Combat can therefore become frustrating as confrontations with thugs are common and it's difficult to know who to shoot first and who to leave for a struggle kill with your machete.This isn't the only time tactics are needed for conserving resources, however, as Professor Cox regains health and stamina through the rare packets of food and drink that he finds perched on outcrops and crates by a fellow survivor who presumably didn't want to make things to easy for those after him. The game revolves around stamina and climbing as Professor Brian must scale increasingly dizzying heights during each episode. Despite his PhD in physics, the Professor's stamina depletes frighteningly quickly making each section of climbing a nail-biting game of tactics. Thankfully, as seen above, Brian can have snacks while hanging from girders to give him a boost. How this is meant to work in real life exactly I have no idea.So what happens when the Professor falls to his death, or some thugs grow tired of hearing about eleven-dimensional M-theory and slaughter him with machetes? Well, on "Normal" mode he'll be given three retries for each "episode" which will allow him to revert to a checkpoint a few minutes of gameplay back. It soon becomes apparent, however, that given the maze-like webs of scaffolding Professor Cox must negotiate and how difficult is to know which enemies to eliminate first on so few bullets, these retries really aren't enough. It's not uncommon to have to retry up to twenty minutes of gameplay following a clumsy death near the end of one "episode". The game only saves at the end of each 20-30 minute episode, so get ready to sit down for long periods at a time with this game.Although we're used to Brian gazing dreamily up at the stars as though he wouldn't hurt a fly, the game's moral direction is altogether more ambiguous. You're rewarded for helping injured survivors and reuniting friends and family, but more frequently you're forced into combat you don't want or need. I would have liked to have seen a less linear path through levels, with some scope for stealth and avoiding conflict.When the game works, it works well and flows nicely. Although some of the events in the game feel jarringly too convenient (early on an earthquake pushes over a building, allowing you to slide down the wall back to where you started form and the next checkpoint), a dark atmosphere draws you in and it's hard to resist helping Professor Brian back to the university in time for his next lecture on electron potential wells.

content:
Posted: April 30, 2013
												I Am Alive was once a survival horror game with big dreams and high hopes. When first conceived, it was purposed to be set in an explorable, expansive, post-apocalyptic world with deep gameplay mechanics focused on human interaction in times of crises. But two years after its ambitious beginnings, the original developers, Darkworks, handed the project off to Ubisoft Shanghai. In its new home, I Am Alive was rebuilt as an arcade title with many of its intended features either removed or condensed. So how does it fare in its current state?I had not heard much about I Am Alive prior to release, but if its original narrative was anything like the final product, then the idea probably was not very good to begin with. The game takes place a year after America is struck by a massive earthquake known as “The Event.” You play as an unnamed survivor, separated from and in search of his family—at least, that is how the story begins. The plot makes a sudden shift early in the game and becomes centered on the protagonist helping reunite someone else’s family for the remainder of the campaign. By the time we reach the end credits, our protagonist’s personal mission has made almost no progress. Some may find this hugely unsatisfying, though I suppose in some ways, it is poetic and fitting to such a morbid game.While I Am Alive’s narrative is devoid of creativity, its gameplay mechanics fortunately are not. Being aware of your surrounding is pivotal to survival. “The Event” has left much of America uninhabitable, filling the atmosphere with ash and dust, and to escape the hazardous environment, you must scale structures high enough to reach fresh air. This process eventually loses its novelty after the first few times, but it deters players from rushing and encourages exploration. But the most innovate idea I Am Alive offers is the idea to threaten and bluff. I say “idea” because its implementation is just deeply, deeply flawed. During confrontations, you may raise your pistol, loaded or not, to halt enemies in their tracks. At this point, the ability to negotiate would have been a hugely welcomed feature, but alas, the system never gets deeper. The moment you look away, your enemies will attack, rendering threats extremely useless since you are forced to kill regardless.I Am Alive’s single redeeming element is its atmosphere, which captures all the greatest facets of survival horror. The thick dust at ground level obscures vision beyond a few feet from your character. The element of surprise comes from not knowing who or what you will run into until it is too late. Ammo is extremely scarce, and your character is fragile, so knowing when to flee or fight becomes essential. Dying NPCs taking refuge throughout the city convey a genuine sense of desperation and futility. This is survival horror done right.Atmosphere and missed ideas aside, nothing else about I Am Alive is very memorable. The graphics are bland, the soundtrack forgettable, and the animations clunky at best. There are side quests, but those are far and few in between. Remnants of Darkworks’ original ideas are still apparent in the final product, but all of them marred by poor execution. I sincerely hope that Darkworks’ vision will resurface one day, refined and in all its entirety. Until then, you should find your survival horror fix elsewhere.Grade: 2/5

content:

												"I Am Alive" is set in a post-apocalyptic world, with few survivors struggling for life. Although being more about trial and error than giving you fair chances of survival sometimes, the game is very atmospheric and gives you lot's of important choices: will you spend your last water to a man in need or will you keep it for yourself, giving you the edge in your fight through the remnats of a destroyed city?Graphics, sound and game mechanis are okay, but not stunning. But if you're into the theme of "survival in a post-apocalyptic world", "I Am Alive" is worth a shot.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 26, 2012
												Feels like an interactive movie, not only in terms of ambience but also in terms of moral decisions. The game is based on 3 major concepts: A)  Carefully manage your human constitution and dexterity. I Am Alive does its best to constantly remind you that you  are human and fragile. A realistic moving/climbing system alongside a revolutionary psycological combat system play their part in this as well.B) Explore. But do so with consequences. You might find something of use or you might use all your supplies for nothing. C) Help others in need, however make sure that helping them doesn't jeopardise your own survival. Moral decisions are often in I Am Alive and the game does not really reward you for the right choice. There is no right choice and the only reward comes from your own morality and mentality of living.If you are a fan of I Am Legend, but you are too old for mindless zombie killing then this is the title for you.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 9, 2013
												I am a survivor. I Am Alive. This game throws the player into a crumbling post-apocalyptic city, armed with pistol but no bullets. Resources are scarce, and survival is brutal. Combat becomes a game of deception and intimidation. Traversing a destroyed city will see you climbing everywhere you go, but the stamina system makes each climb potentially deadly. Success will depend on resource management more than anything else, as each bullet or bottle of water is precious. Some aspects of the game are quite repetitive or tedious, but this was not overly noticeable within the 6 hours of gameplay it took me to finish.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 5, 2013
												I Am Alive is a survival game which focuses on heavy player choices and immersing the player. While i thought the game was really good and worth the money some may not and here is why:Dated graphicsClunky controlsAnd a buggy camera which sometimes won't move.But me being a fan of post apocalyptic themes i decided to look past all of this and what i saw was awesome, while not all will like that kind of gameplay i loved it. You are able to bluff enemies with a empty gun but some of them will stop up and say your full of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t and encourage others to attack. I thought that was a awesome thing i had not seen before, you also need to switch targets sometimes to keep them afraid of being shot. Another key factor is the extremely rare supplies which you need but you only have 3 retry's or you have to start over. Additional retry's can be aquired by giving away supplies and medicine to people, so that keeps the game tense.The soundtrack which i found really good is also a indicator for when climbing buildings since the soundtrack becomes more intense as you lose stamina. 0 stamina results in falling down and dying.Overall i found the game to be really good and worth my money since i played it three times. But keep in mind this is a arcade game so it only last for about 5 hours on average.Presentation: 7.0Graphics: 7.0Sound: 8.0Game-play: 8.0Lasting Appeal: 9.0Overall Rating: 8.5

content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												Ok, just made it through the game, which seems to be a mixture of survival, adventure, climbing and TPS/FPS. Here's the results:Pro:+ Story. Grounded, realistic - not off-hook or with irrational twists.+ Setting/atmosphere. Dark and dusty, gloomy undertone without being pathetic.+ The voice-acting! A real big plus. Little Mei has the most realistic and beautiful voice for a kid I ever experienced in a video game.Cons.- Graphics. Obviously it's a console port. You have to live with that.- Game time. It only takes about six hours for a complete game. Well, as there are survivors to save, this time could be extended if you want to find and help them all (20 altogether). Otherwise replayability's low.- Controls. They are a pain. If you're used to play FPS games, you will have a hard time learning the controls. don't be frustrated to lose your first fights because you pressed the wrong buttons. It's a console game after all, maybe the devs did not want to screw up the game mechanics by changing controls on pc. who knows.Conclusion: You might have a look if you're into survival, like a gloomy atmosphere and don't expect innovative gameplay or experiences.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2014
												I'm a little unsure how I feel about the game overall. It's got some strong, cool stuff - the dusty visuals are great, and a lot of the gameplay is genuinely intense and suspenseful. Combat has some clever ideas, especially bluffing and false (or real) surrenders, though it's overused in the final chapters. There are some control annoyances (though the camera problem seems to be specific to the PC version). And the thing that bugs me the most is how the story claims to be about one man's journey to find his family, but really that's the backdrop for a story about one man's journey to find someone else's family.The game is cheap, though, so it could still be worth your time. The camera problem I experienced apparently isn't present in the console versions, so if you're interested, I'd recommend playing it on XBox or PS3.Full review here: http://postlaunch.blogspot.ca/2013/01/i-am-alive.html

content:
Posted: December 26, 2016
												Pro: Your decisions feel like they have consequences.Con but also a Pro: You often do not get to decide (unless death is a choice) and those consequences can make you look like a monster. Pro: The story is compelling.Con: The story telling is disjointed, lacking content and feels linear despite not moving the story forward one bit.Pro: Combat is intense (because of the story content in the mechanics).Con: The only combat scenarios not First-Person-Shooter (FPS) are Quick-Time-Events (QTE) and the game is lacking in mechanics for non-FPS resolutions to conflict.The game music pretty much tells you if there's an enemy nearby which detracts from any need to be subtle, secret or careful.Buy this game for the story.  The concept is good. The story is alright. The combat is rubbish. The execution needs considerable work and the graphics are not optimized. It's worth getting on sale for under $10 for the concept alone. The climbing, the environment, the story though lacking all tied together to push me foward. It felt like Tomb Raider in a post apocalyptic dystopian wasteland amidst the crumbling remains of a once bustling city.

content:
Posted: December 8, 2016
												After a series of battles with 3 different groups of thugs, me armed only with a gun with 1 single bullet and a machette, I'm giving up on this game.  Like others have said, it is kill or be killed - there is no other option.  And killing others is downright tough!  EVERY encounter with thugs results in me dying at least a few times before I get it right, made all the more difficult by the camera, which is programmed to automatically focus on one thug at a time.  The result is that after I perform a surprise kill with the machete, the camera focuses on whoever is in my current line of signt, even if the remaining gun-toting thug is behind me.  So although I need to do a quick surprise kill + shoot the last gunslinger, I end up shooting some dude clear across the courtyard who is armed with a knife, and then get shot in the back of the head by the guy I was struggling to aim at, who was standing right behind/next to me - oh the ignominy!These battles have become so un-fun that I don't care to play the game anymore.  I might watch it on youtube, though, just to find out what happens :)

number of helpful: 7 of 16 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 30, 2016
												I Am Alive was a really good Xbox arcade game, with a subpar PC port that costs way too much after 4 years.Graphically this game is beautiful, but at the same time is almost a direct port from console with no extra effort put in to make it look better on PC, meaning it lacks the full gamut of options a game intended for PC would have. The desaturated color pallette common to movies and games that share similar themes like Fallout, The Road, Rage, Book of Eli, Mad Max and other post apocalyptic media fits the game perfectly. Unfortunately, it also garnered the game a lot of negative attention from whining casuals who only see overall trends in gaming and don't judge games based on their merits.I Am Alive is the story of a guy who was away from home when weather disasters destroyed the world [ostensibly] and has spent every moment since trying to get back to his wife and daughter. The game combines recognizable platforming with beautiful post-civilization landscapes, but also features melee and gun combat more akin to a realistic survival game (at least until the latter part of the game where you get a lot of ammo). Ammo is scarce and healing items more scarce. Everyone you encounter is an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ trying to kill you, and even some of the people you try to rescue will try to trick you into being killed like a lot of random NPCs in Witcher 3 or GTA5 will do.The story is predictable, and I'm not sure if the title of the game is supposed to be ironic or not, but I wish that the Chinese sect of Ubisoft that developed this were working on a full fledged sequel or re-imagining. Really the negative aspects of this game are the low fidelity graphics and the awful controller support on PC - not to mention the obvious lack of Steamworks integration for things like achievements.  I really wish the controller mapping was functional, because it makes this game all but unplayable on computer.If you can look past that or use something like Controller Companion, this game is worth the time of anyone who likes platformers or post-civilization games.

number of helpful: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 18, 2014
												Absolutely a massively underated game. Yes its an xbox 360 port but with the new patch update and controller support, its quite beautiful in two ways. Graphically, yes its dated graphically but atmospherically it more than makes up for it. I personally really like the washed, sun bleached look. It all works brilliantly to be another character in itself. Bleak, dusty and desperate. You will stair in wonder at the sun glare and vista's through broken building windows, but despair about looking down to the dust soup below that you know you have to delve into.          The second positive is its combat is a really great attempt at different. You are taught to think about using the tools they give you with such an incredibly limited ammo supply, seriously limited. I have used the same one arrow for my bow in nearly every battle.           The added genius of a taunt option where you threaten with your pistol so that thugs back away at its sight and beg not be shot is great. However they will grow in confidence if you taunt to much and call your bluff realising that the gun is actually empty. Then they may attack, so will you machete, use the bow or run. You will die in this game, but each time it teaches you this is survival, so survive. It has a very standard but competent climbing and traversing mechanic which does its job well with good animation, although our hero does choose his own path occasionally.          If I have one gripe its that the save system is spread out quite a bit and when you have exhausted your in-between checkpoint tokens, gathered for saving civilians along the way, you will be sent back quite a way to a previous save point, and with this loose a lot progress that you may have made. This game rewards exploration if you wish to risk it but with such intermitant saves points it also holds exploration back somewhat which is its only slight issue. For a couple of pounds on steam, even if you pay a fiver i highly recommend this little gem. Think 'Shadow of the collosus' meets 'the last of us' and you are there.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 22, 2014
												Every time I see this game in my library, I'm ashamed I payed money for it. Unless you enjoy excessively long and redundant climbing puzzles that are incredibly slow and boring, this game is not for you. Combat usually consists of... 1) See enemy. 2) Shoot enemy with gun. 3) engage in quick time event to kill the other enemies, mashing the same button over and over, hoping one of the other enemies doesn't decide they want to attack you while you are stuck in a QTE (Quick time event). ALL combat aside from firearms and sneak kills are QTEs.The exploration might be fun, if not for the blurred graphics to try to make it look better. The textures didn't look nice, so they just blurred everything. Oh yeah, the game has next to no color, so everything looks pretty similar. Movement is really clunky and the climbing is obnoxiously slow and unneccesary. Oh yeah, if you are having trouble with a section, the game will make it harder by lowering your max stamina. So in an exploration game, they discourage exploring while climbing so you don't get an obnoxious lessened max stamina, make everything look incredibly boring, and make the occasional encounter pretty underwhelming too. Ever get that feeling where you get an objective in a game and it becomes and irritation and a chore? That's basically this entire game. (Most of the exploration I found was just someone telling you to backtrack to somewhere you have already been. /:) I was incredibly disapointed by this game.

content:
Posted: October 23, 2016
												I really wanted to like this game, I really did! There are so many concepts that could have led to a good game but it just didnt work out after all.The character moves very clumsy and laggy, what would have been kind of an important part for a game where it is all about the movement. During the first 30 minutes the atmosphere was very nice but dropped quickly after. One thing that could have got me is the combat system, if it wasnt so repetetive and dull after a few fights. I might even have kept going if the story and encounters were any good but even that was too weak and slow.I did like the concept of stamina, climbing and the fighting mechanics but like I said, I couldnt just enjoy it after all and deinstalled it after 2 1/2 hours because it just wasnt worth the time.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 24, 2014
												My mother always told me that if I didn't have anything nice to say, I shouldn't say anything at all, and to that end, I can say that I thought the 3D platforming elements of this game were well done, if linear.  I constantly felt like I was in danger of falling off in a number of cases.  Unfortunately, there was one bit of "danger" music and it began to lose its punch after a while.  While there were a number of excellent city views in this game, a lot of my time also seemed to be spent with so much lens flare I could hardly see or with such an aggressive grain filter that it felt like I needed cataract surgery.  There were some interesting gameplay elements that became somewhat repetitive, but I felt like none of them ever really shined.  The exploration is fairly minimal, the plot is generic and never feels like it's really resolved, the survival aspect is somewhat tame.  I had an issue on my laptop where the ground would pop in and out depending on camera angle (I did not have this problem on my desktop, though my laptop more than meets system requirements as well).  There was one section that I was entirely unable to complete, but found a way to climb around it after a couple hours (much of it spent getting there from the previous checkpoint which was some way back as they are not very frequent).Ultimately, I think there's a market for this game, but it wasn't me.

content:
Posted: September 11, 2012
												I Am Alive is an atmospheric apocalyptic survivor game shown from a third person perspective.  The visuals and music are haunting and the the voice acting compliments the eery mood well.  Unfortunately the game shipped in a broken state and shockingly the xbox 360 controller for PC does not work and there is no workaround short of using a third party program to map through your keyboard.  This is shameful especially considering the game is a port.  It's sad that a large publisher like Ubisoft would not rush to fix such a major bug.  Someday I Am Alive might be worth the price, but as it stands I recommend gamers stay away from this broken product.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2015
ENGLISH and Italian Review Recensione Inglese ed ITALIANA English:Talking about this game ain't easy. It starts with the best premises: An immersive post-apochaliptyc atmosphere, a peculiar gameplay and a nice character story. BUT, it has an incorporated achievement system, so it doesen't use the Steam one. And that's a thing that i HATE. Because it makes achievements totally useless. The only reason of having an achievement system, it's to have them saved in your account, so you can then be satisfied and show them off. If you can't do that, they're useless. But that's the least. It doesen't investigate the catastrophe AT ALL. You don't know why, you don't know how. It lasts 6 hours MAX, counting the eventual failures. And the end is... is frickin fast. What do i mean for fast? Well, from the last mission onwards i had that feeling, like the developers had a short-term to finish the game, so they finished fit quickly and poorly. The last mission is just an enormus exaggerate and unrealistic fight with tons of enemies and the finale, well... You dead. Wanna know how? Wanna know why? lol, no, you dead. You just see your daughter (Or wife, i can't really remember) that found your camera, watches your videos and cries. And you?? Well, you dead, lol. ...So, the end isn't that great. No deep and too fast. And so much disappointing. That said, i can't really vote "NO" 'cause despite everything i enjoyed this little game a bit. Exluding the finale. The feeling i had, was of an hypothetical The Last Of Us, made quickly and on very low budget. If other than "YES" and "NO" there was a "A LITTLE BIT" option on the Steam reviews, i would pick that. But, for now, i feel forced to click "YES". (Sorry for my bad english)Italiano:Parlare di questo gioco non è facile. Inizia con le migliori premesse: Atmosfera post apocalittica immersiva, gameplay particolare e storia carina. Poi però ha un sistema di achievement incorporato, non usa quello di Steam. Ed è una cosa che personalmente DETESTO, perché rende gli achievement totalmente inutili. L'unico motivo degli achievement è poterli avere salvati sull'account e poterli mettere in mostra, e non puoi. Ma questo è il minimo. Non approfondisce il perché della catastrofe, neanche un po'. Dura al massimo 6 ore e qualcosa contando fallimenti vari ed eventuali, e la fine è sbrigativa. Cosa intendo per sbrigativa? Dalla missione finale in poi si ha questa sensazione, come se gli sviluppatori avessero una scadenza corta e avessero buttato il finale a caso in fretta e furia. L'ultima missione è semplicemente un gigante combattimento esagerato agli estremi, dunque poco realistico, ed il finale, beh.. Muori. Ma non è che vedi il personaggio che muore eh, semplicemente una breve cutscene mostra tua figlia (O tua moglie, sinceraente non ricordo) che trova la tua videocamera e piange. Fine del gioco. Tu sei morto, e non hai riabbracciato tua figlia. Come sei morto non si sa. Ma sei morto. Molto poco profondo e molto sbrigativo. E molto deludente. Detto questo, non mi sento però di votare "NO" perché nonostante tutto come esperienza di gioco non è stata catastrofica, tutto sommato, finale a parte, il gioco non mi è dispiaciuto. La sensazione che ho avuto, è stata quella di un ipotetico The Last Of Us creato di fretta e a basso budget. Ecco, se oltre a "SI" e "NO" ci fosse l'opzione "FORSE" per le recensioni, utilizzerei quella. Ma fino a che non implementeranno un'opzione del genere, mi vedo costretto a premere "SI".

number of helpful: 2 of 7 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 24, 2016
												I Am Alive is boring. Everything about it is boring. There's nearly no color anywhere, boring characters, weak atmosphere, nearly nonexistant story, simple gameplay, and more. The graphics are pretty below average, and shadows are god awful. It's not fun to play through. It's hard to believe I ended up completing the game back on the Xbox 360.I think the main problem is the devs. Maybe a post apocalyptic story based game isn't their thing. This game has hope, and it sounds good on paper. You play as a man (I can't remember his name because he's such a weak character) that ventures back into NYC after a series of earthquakes collapses the city upon itself. It's a bit fun to traverse the city, but the climbing and stamina system is so bad, it's not that much fun. I think, in the rights hand, I Am Alive could've been a great game, but Ubisoft Shanghei failed to create a great game around some rather interesting lore. I got this game on a sale for $3.75, but I'm gonna get a Steam refund and probably use that on trading cards or something. Or wait and see if a good game goes on sale for that price.Should you get it? No, not really. Watch some videos first to see if it looks fun to you before buying if you're still really interested in this game.

												Great concept for a game, its interesting, I like the stamina system and the enemy interactions are good however its really repetitive and the combat feels really scripted and boring.Enemy combat usually involves, observe who has a gun, surprise attack the gun person, quickly shoot the other gun guy with your one single bullet you managed to find and then get in a mouse button mash contest with the enemy with the knife. number of helpful: 0 of 3 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 10, 2012
												A great post-apocaliptic game to enjoy, I Am Alive follows unnamed protagonist who tries to find his family in city Haventon destroyed by earthquake. As you progress you will be able to find diffrent resources like water and food, and later use them to replenish your stamina and health bar, so you will be able to move and climb up different hights. While the graphics look ok there is not enough to look at as whole city is in ruins and it's surrounded with moody glooms and dark colors. Gameplay is ok although it is repetitive.You will climb up different building to avoid death from polluted air, you will fight off bad guys with empty gun and machete(and later bow with arrows which is cool).There are also those who will ask you to deliver specific items to help them in return they will give you "retry"so you will be able to continue game if you make a mistake during your playthrough.All in all it's very original game and should be given a chance to prove itself but 15$ is too much.7.5/10

content:
Posted: August 11, 2016
THIS GAME SCORES [0 *1* | 2 3] = ~38% (25%-50%)(Might even only be 1of4, but I haven't seen enough of the game to judge.)"I Am Alive" could have been good, but my experiences suggest that its game design in general is just bad.I get the ammo shortage idea, but the result the first time I came across it was this: 1) I had one bullet. Encountered a situation where I couldn't figure out a solution other than firing that one bullet. 2) Ten minutes later, I was at a fence or something, and crawling through the hole started a cutscene that I had no way of knowing would happen (So, my survival that supposedly depends on my decisions and how I balance stuff suddenly was very obviously tied to arbitrary game designer choices.), and when the cutscene was over, I was inside the fenced area and had only seconds to save my life. That's really bad game design by itself (just sucking me in there without a warning, when the rest of the game screams "This is a simulation! You act and decide!"), but on top of that:The situation that unfolded seemed dynamic, but no matter how hard I tried to avoid it: I got shot dead. Running/hiding was no option. So, since I had used my one bullet already in a situation that called for it, I was now stuck in a "5 attempts left ... no, 4 ... 3" loop that was just pure frustration, and it was at that time that a suspicion grew to certainty: This game is actually bad.When I tried again, I respawned a lot earlier in the game, so in combination with the accumulated frustration and the reasonable estimate that the rest of the game would have more such crappy game design decisions, I abandoned it entirely. Would have been a refund, but back then we didn't have that luxury yet.Btw., the very gimmicky and tediously slow climbing-on-rails situations didn't help, either.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2016
												So I wanted to see if Ubisoft Shanghai would've hired me for an accounting or marketing position. I have a nice and stable career, but I always romanticized to work in the gaming industry. I sent them my resume and went to their office for an interview - all just out of curiosity. They asked me if I played any of their games. I have not played any of their games because I only use one DRM (Steam), I don't use Uplay, Origin, the Windows' or Blizzard's DRM, etc. On my way out I asked if they could tell me the name of their games I could check out. They told me about their "Tom Clancy's EndWar" game, also they gave me a list of a bunch of local mobile games, and they mentioned their soon-to-be-released game "I Am Alive". A couple years later I finally checked out their game "I Am Alive" and I'm happy that I did not join that company! 


I pass their office on my way to work almost every day.

content:
Posted: October 11, 2013
												it looks like the areas in The Last of Us - but it´s some years older than it."I am alive" is a frustrating game because you WILL often die in the game.If enemies want to kill you, you only have a chance to survive if you collect and use wisely ammo for your first weapon - to use your weapon when it´s really necessary. It´s really necessary if three or four enemies attack you - then you have to be really quick. But i want to say again that it´s nearly impossible to defeat three or more enemies in one try. That´s the "core-thing" in this game - to be alive and kill nearly everyone who you see (but there are not so many people in the apocalyptic areas).I hated to repeat the positions in the game where i tried to survive and was killed again and again.That´s the reason why i was going to hate the game nearly - but the awsome story motivates me to play the game further and love it.(only play the game with the xbox 360 game controller for windows - otherwise it will be impossible to play it clean)The exiting "jump-and-survive-missions" at broken towers, bridges and railings make this game feel like you are a mountaineer (like Altair or Ezio from Assassins Creed), who risk his life to see his wife and little daughter. This game is one of the best apocalyptic and withal saddest games ever - made by ubisoft ! For me it´s one of the best games ever. It´s not too short and not too long ! Buy it if you like games with a good story ;-)

												Wow - I Am Disappointed.  Could be a fantastic game but the controls are . . . stupid.  Button mash to run faster, button mash for "extreme effort" while climbing, button mash to pry open locked gates.  Poor console port and no excuse for that these days.The game does have a great atmosphere and setting but with so-so graphics, poor gameplay and button mashing coupled with what should be great survival gameplay, sadly dumbed down to pick up the glowy objects and ignore everything else, this could have been a great game.SO much climbing - and it's slow and boring.  I sort of like the climbing stamina drain because, really, your arms would eventually get tired.  Then again climbing for such a short time causing exhaustion when you play a fit person who obviously knows how to climb is a bit silly.Ah, but it has a post apocalyptic feel so I had to buy it because I love the genre.  Sadly only a short time with this game is making me so frustrated I almost wish I hadn't spent 15 bucks.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 22, 2013
												A great post-apocalyptic survival game that's actually realistic. No zombies or mutants here, just the harsh environment and other people trying to survive. Food, items and ammo are scarce, and it really makes you think about conserving every bullet and morsel of food. Your actions in each situation can have big ramifications. Do you quickly draw your pistol and shoot a thug (and waste a bullet in the process), or threaten him with your loaded pistol and hope he backs off. Do you give your last can of food to a starving survivor, or keep it for yourself for when you need it the most. I found this game thought provoking and it left an emotional impact on me. Highly recommended for anyone wanting to play something more grounded in realism than the usual "blockbuster" style action game...

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 21, 2014
												I would reccomed this game to others, but only if you get it on sale like I did. It was very suspensful and SUPER creepy. The layout and mapping system reminded me of Silent Hill Downpour, but the movement was a little like Assasians Creed. You are able to climb up skyscrapers, sparta kick people into firepits, use a crossbow, and much much more. Although, it was a little confusing on where you should go sometimes it was still pretty awesome. It was a shorter game, but there are some achievements that you can get.      The storyline was a little off. I wish that it showed more of him trying to get to his family instead of helping anothers. It left off on a cliffhanger, and I'm not too fond of it. Also, the checkpoints were your saving points. There is no place for you to save your game, becuase it automatically does so. That was probably the most annoying part of the game. (Besides the ridiculous solar contrasted rays of light in your eyes)      As for the items, there was always a supply of them. I never had any issues, except when climbing with the pitons. My only advice would be to use certain items sparingly (piton, bullets, medkits etc.) The other items (canned food/fruit, water, soda, painkillers, etc.) were always available if you looked around and scavenged. I ended the game with a lot more than what I needed.      Altogether, I thought that this was a very good game. It was really fun to play, and I would give it an 8/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 16, 2014
												Well, what to say? This game is prime example of missed opportunity for something extraordinary, but it failed on some crucial steps... but has shine on other. Game has some interesting and decent game mechanics and it plays good for most of time. There is occasional fighting with controls and weird key mapping on PC (you can change it) but nothing serious or unfixable. Atmosphere of game is phenomenal; torn up town looks amazing and feels real; even if at closer inspection lack of texture details and low poly models are quite visible, that is not "deal breaker".Main problem with game is story, ending and length; game can be finished in some 5h (I have repeat some areas to help all victims, so my overall play time was longer) and I got feeling like I just have started to play it. And even game it self went in direction like it will continue for at least 10h... but then it cuts and roles credits...Main character story never get's resolved while ending ruins any potential for sequels (I won't spoil it).Over all, game looks like it was rushed to be finished while production was still at 1/3 of development, so they just made cut there, made up some stupid ending and "VOILA!" game is done! And it's sad that potential this game had, was ruined in such stupid way...  And I can recommend it, but keep in mind what I have said; if that doesn't bother you and you want to feel great atmosphere game has, go for it (but get it on some BIG discount).Over all rating: 5/10

content:
Posted: April 17, 2014
												Short but sweet, this is worth it if you can get it on sale. While the gameplay can be glitchy at times (often when I died, my gun remained in are while my body fell; once my body disappeared while playing), it's nothing that hampers gameplay.  And though the textures can be bland, the graphics are snazzed up by the fx, and look darn cool if you push this into the indie game category (which is really where it fits in to). For those looking for a Fallout fix, however, this is not quite the right game for you. This is not an expansive role playing game in which to emerse yourself. This game more of an indie gamers 'realistic' take on the post-apocalyptic genre (conserving ammo and supplies, tricking enemies. etc). I enjoyed it a lot, especially since it didn't cost me much to buy.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 19, 2014
												My first review was a negative one, as it wouldn't run on Windows 8.1. Although you get a message of incompatibility during instalation on Windows 10, it runs perfectly. I'm truly enjoying it. Combat is a little rough on the edges, but the climbing is fine. The AI is decent. The best thing about it is that it's not "shoot on sight", from both player's and NPC's perspectives. Of course some will try and kill you, but others are just waving a gun at your face to protect their belongings. There are the ones who doubt you have bullets - a VERY common scenario - and just go berserk and you have to kill them anyways. Some even surrender.It's a post-apocalyptic "save it for a rainy day" Silent Hill. I like it and almost didn't buy it because of criticism. If you're into survival and Silent Hill, go for it.
